name: Norm Definition
statement:
Let $X$ be a vector space (over either $F = \mathbb{R}$ or $F = \mathbb{C}$). A norm $\| \cdot \| : X \to \mathbb{R}$ is a function so that $\forall x, y \in X, \forall\lambda \in F$

(N1) $\|x\| \geq 0$ with $\|x\| = 0 \Leftrightarrow x = 0$

(N2) $\|\lambda x\| = |\lambda|\|x\|$

(N3) $\|x + y\| \leq \|x\| + \|y\|$ (Triangle inequality)

We call a pair $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ a normed space.

name: Banach Space
statement: A normed space $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ is a Banach space if it is complete, i.e. if every Cauchy sequence in $X$ converges.

name: Subspace Completeness
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a Banach space, $Y \\subset X$ a subspace. Then\n\n$(Y, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ is complete $\\Leftrightarrow$ $Y \\subset X$ is closed.
Rightarrow$\\: nLet $(y_n)$ be so that $y_n \\in Y$, $y_n \\to x \\in X$. Then $(y_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence in $Y$ so converges in $(Y, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ to some $y \\in Y$. Hence $x = y \\in Y$ by uniqueness of limits. Hence $Y$ is closed.\n\n\
$\\\\Leftarrow$\\: n\nIf $(y_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence in $(Y, \\| \\cdot \\|)$, it is also a Cauchy sequence in $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ and must hence converge in $X$, say $y_n \\to x \\in X$. But as $Y$ is closed we must have that $x \\in Y$ and hence that $(y_n)$ converges in $(Y, \\| \\cdot \\|)$. Thus $Y$ is complete.

name: Hölder's inequality
statement:
For $1 \leq p, q \leq \infty$ with

$(\star)$ $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$

we have that for any $x, y \in \mathbb{C}^n$

$\sum_{i=1}^{n} |x_i y_i| \leq \|x\|_p\|y\|_q$.

In $(\star)$ we use the convention that $\frac{1}{p} = 0$ for $p = \infty$, and one often calls numbers $p, q \in [1, \infty]$ satisfying $(\star)$ conjugate exponents.
proof: The proof of this inequality (both for $\\mathbb{C}^n$ as well as the analogues for the sequence and function spaces $\\ell^p$ and $L^p$) can be found in most textbooks and is left as an exercise.

name: Cauchy Subsequence
statement:
Let $(x_n)$ be a Cauchy sequence in a normed space $(X, \| \cdot \|)$. Then the following are equivalent:

(i) $(x_n)$ converges,

(ii) $(x_n)$ has a convergent subsequence.
proof:
(i) $\Rightarrow$ (ii) is trivial.

(ii) $\Rightarrow$ (i)

Suppose $x_{n_k} \to x$. Given any $\varepsilon > 0$, we can choose $N$ so that for all $n, m \geq N$

$\|x_n - x_m\| < \varepsilon/2$

and furthermore choose $K$ so that for $k \geq K$

$\|x_{n_k} - x\| < \varepsilon/2$.

Then for $n \geq N$ we have, choosing some $k \geq K$ so that $n_k \geq N$,

$\|x - x_n\| \leq \|x - x_{n_k}\| + \|x_{n_k} - x_n\| < \varepsilon/2 + \varepsilon/2 = \varepsilon$.

name: Absolute Convergence
statement:
Let $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ be a normed space. Then the following are equivalent

(i) $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ is a Banach space,

(ii) Absolute convergence of series implies convergence, i.e. for sequences $(x_n)$ in $X$ and the corresponding partial sums $s_n := \sum_{k=1}^n x_k$ we have

$\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \|x_n\| < \infty \Rightarrow s_n$ converges to some $s \in X$.
proof:
(i) $\Rightarrow$ (ii)
If $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \|x_n\| < \infty$ then $s_n$ is a Cauchy sequence in $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ since for $m > n \geq N$

$\|s_n - s_m\| = \|\sum_{k=n+1}^{m} x_k\| \leq \sum_{k=n+1}^{m} \|x_k\| \leq \sum_{k=N+1}^{\infty} \|x_k\| \to 0$ as $N \to \infty$.

As $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ is complete we thus obtain that $s_n$ converges to some element $s \in X$.

(ii) $\Rightarrow$ (i)

Let $(x_n)$ be a Cauchy sequence. Select a subsequence $x_{n_j}$ so that

$\|x_{n_j} - x_{n_{j+1}}\| \leq 2^{-j}$,

where the existence of such a subsequence is ensured by the fact that $x_n$ is Cauchy. Then $\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \|x_{n_{j+1}} - x_{n_j}\| \leq 1 < \infty$ so (ii) ensures that $\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}(x_{n_{j+1}} - x_{n_j})$ converges. Hence $x_{n_k} = x_{n_1} + \sum_{j=1}^{k-1} (x_{n_{j+1}} - x_{n_j})$ converges, so $(x_n)$ has a convergent subsequence and must thus, by Lemma 1.1.7, itself converge.

name: Incomplete Spaces
statement: We can construct many examples of non-complete spaces by equipping a well known space such as $C_b$, $C^1$, $\\ell^p$, $L^p$ with the 'wrong' norm, or by choosing a subspace of a Banach space that is not closed. As an example we show that $C^0([0, 1])$ equipped with $\\|f\\|_{L^1} = \\int_0^1 |f|dx$ is not complete.
proof:
We give two examples: one by direct argument and the other via Corollary 1.1.8.

Example 1: Let
$g_n(x) = \begin{cases} (2x)^n & \text{for } x \in [0, 1/2),\\ 1 & \text{for } x \in [1/2, 1]. \end{cases}$

For $n < m$, we have
$\|g_n - g_m\|_{L^1} = \int_0^{1/2} [(2x)^n - (2x)^m] dx = \frac{1}{2(n + 1)} - \frac{1}{2(m + 1)}$,

so $(g_n)$ is Cauchy. On the other hand, $(g_n)$ is a decreasing sequence of non-negative functions which is bounded from above by 1. Its pointwise limit is the characteristic function of the interval $[1/2, 1]$. By Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem, $g_n$ converges to $\chi_{[1/2,1]}$ in $L^1$ and this limit is discontinuous, hence not in $C([0, 1])$. In other words $(g_n)$ has no limit in $C([0, 1])$.

Example 2: For
$f_n(x) := \begin{cases} 1 - n^2x & \text{for } x \in [0, \frac{1}{n^2}] \\ 0 & \text{else} \end{cases}$

we have that $\|f_n\|_{L^1} = \frac{1}{2n^2}$ so $\sum \|f_n\|_{L^1}$ converges. However $\sum f_n$ cannot converge to an element of $C([0, 1])$. Indeed suppose, seeking a contradiction, that $\sum f_n \to f$ converges in $L^1$ to a function $f \in C([0, 1])$. Then, as continuous functions on compact sets are bounded, there exists some $M \in \mathbb{R}$ so that $f \leq M$ on $[0, 1]$. Hence choosing $N \in \mathbb{N}$ so that $N \geq 2(M + 1)$ we obtain that for any $n \geq N$ and any $x \in [0, \frac{1}{2N^2}]$

$\sum_{j=1}^n f_j(x) - f(x) \geq \sum_{j=1}^N \frac{1}{2} - f(x) \geq N/2 - M \geq 1$

and thus in particular $\|\sum_{j=1}^n f_j - f\|_{L^1} \geq \frac{1}{2N^2} \not\to 0$.

name: Polynomial Space Incompleteness
statement: The space of polynomials on $\\mathbb{R}$ admits no complete norms.
proof: This is a consequence of the Baire category theorem, which will be proved in B4.2 Functional Analysis 2: A complete metric space is never a countable union of nowhere dense subsets. (A nowhere dense set is a set whose closure has empty interior.) Clearly the space of polynomials is a countable union of the spaces of polynomials of degree $\\leq n$. It is easy to see that a proper subspace of a space is always nowhere dense. The incompleteness of the space of polynomials follows.

name: Inner Product
statement:
An inner (scalar) product in a linear vector space $X$ over $\mathbb{R}$ is a real-valued function on $X \times X$, denoted as $\langle x, y \rangle$, having the following properties:

(i) Bilinearity. For fixed $y$, $\langle x, y \rangle$ is a linear function of $x$, and for fixed $x$, $\langle x, y \rangle$ is a linear function of $y$.

(ii) Symmetry. $\langle x, y \rangle = \langle y, x \rangle$ for all $x, y \in X$.

(iii) Positivity. $\langle x, x \rangle > 0$ for $x \neq 0$.

When $X$ is a vector space over $\mathbb{C}$, $\langle x, y \rangle$ is complex-valued and properties (i) and (ii) are replaced by

(i') Sesquilinearity. For fixed $y$, $\langle x, y \rangle$ is a linear function of $x$, and for fixed $x$, $\langle x, y \rangle$ is a skewlinear function of $y$, i.e.

$\langle ax, y \rangle = a\langle x, y \rangle$ and $\langle x, ay \rangle = \bar{a}\langle x, y \rangle$ for all $a \in \mathbb{C}$, $x, y \in X$.

(ii') Skew symmetry. $\langle x, y \rangle = \overline{\langle y, x \rangle}$ for all $x, y \in X$.

The inner product $\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle$ generates a norm, denoted by $\| \cdot \|$, as follows:

$\|x\| = \langle x, x \rangle^{1/2}$.

name: Cauchy-Schwarz inequality
statement: For $x, y \\in X$, $|\\langle x, y \\rangle| \\leq \\|x\\|\\|y\\|$. Equality holds if and only if $x$ and $y$ are linearly dependent.
proof:
If $y = 0$, the conclusion is clear. Assume henceforth that $y \neq 0$. Replacing $x$ by $ax$ with $|a| = 1$ so that $a\langle x, y \rangle$ is real, we may assume without loss of generality that $\langle x, y \rangle$ is real.

For $t \in \mathbb{R}$, we compute using sesquilinearity and skew symmetry:

$\|x + ty\|^2 = \langle x + ty, x + ty \rangle = \|x\|^2 + 2t \text{Re } \langle x, y \rangle + t^2\|y\|^2$.

By positivity, this quadratic polynomial in $t$ is non-negative for all $t$. This implies that

$(\text{Re } \langle x, y \rangle)^2 - \|x\|^2\|y\|^2 \leq 0$,

which gives the desired inequality. If equality holds, then there is some $t_0$ such that $x + t_0y = 0$. The conclusion follows.

name: Hilbert Space
statement: A linear vector space with an inner product is called an inner product space. If it is complete with the induced norm, it is called a Hilbert space.

name: Euclidean Space
statement: The space $\\mathbb{C}^n$ or $\\mathbb{R}^n$ is a Hilbert space with the standard inner product $\\langle x, y \\rangle = \\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_k \\bar{y}_k$.

name: Sequence Space
statement: The space $\\ell^2 = \\{(x_1, x_2, \\ldots) = (x_n) : \\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty} |x_n|^2 < \\infty\\}$ is a Hilbert space with the inner product $\\langle x, y \\rangle = \\sum_{k=1}^{\\infty} x_k \\bar{y}_k$.

name: Incomplete Inner Product
topic: Inner Product Spaces and Hilbert Spaces
statement: The space $C[0, 1]$ of continuous functions on the interval $[0, 1]$ is an incomplete inner product space with the inner product $\\langle f, g \\rangle = \\int_0^1 f \\overline{g} dx$.

name: L2 Hilbert Space
topic: Inner Product Spaces and Hilbert Spaces
statement: Let $(E, \\mu)$ be a measure space, e.g. $E$ is a subset of $\\mathbb{R}^n$ and $\\mu$ is the Lebesgue measure. The space $L^2(E, \\mu)$ of all complex-valued square integrable functions is a Hilbert space with the inner product $\\langle f, g \\rangle = \\int_E f \\overline{g} d\\mu$. The completeness of $L^2(E, \\mu)$ is a special case of the Riesz-Fischer theorem on the completeness of the Lebesgues space $L^p(E, \\mu)$.

name: Closed Subspace
topic: Inner Product Spaces and Hilbert Spaces
statement: A closed subspace of a Hilbert space is a Hilbert space.

name: Bergman space
topic: Inner Product Spaces and Hilbert Spaces
statement: Let $D$ be the open unit disk in $\\mathbb{C}$. The space $A^2(D)$ consists of all functions which are square integrable and holomorphic in $D$ is a closed subspace of $L^2(D)$ and is thus a Hilbert space.

name: Hardy space
topic: Inner Product Spaces and Hilbert Spaces
statement: The space $H^2(T)$ of all functions $f \\in L^2(-\\pi, \\pi)$ whose Fourier series are of the form $\\sum_{n\\geq 0} a_n e^{inx}$ is a closed subspace of $L^2(-\\pi, \\pi)$ and is thus a Hilbert space.

name: Orthogonal Vectors
statement: Two vectors $x$ and $y$ in an inner product space $X$ are said to be orthogonal if $\\langle x, y \\rangle = 0$.

name: Orthogonal Complement
statement: Let $Y$ be a subset of an inner product space $X$. We define $Y^{\\perp}$ as the space of all vectors $v \\in X$ which are orthogonal to $Y$, i.e. $\\langle v, y \\rangle = 0$ for all $y \\in Y$. When $Y$ is a subspace of $X$, $Y^{\\perp}$ is called the orthogonal complement of $Y$ in $X$.

name: Orthogonal Complement Properties
statement:
Let $Y$ be a subset of an inner product space $X$. Then

(i) $Y^{\perp}$ is a closed subspace of $X$.

(ii) $Y \subset Y^{\perp\perp}$.

(iii) If $Y \subset Z \subset X$, then $Z^{\perp} \subset Y^{\perp}$.

(iv) $(\text{span } Y)^{\perp} = Y^{\perp}$.

(v) If $Y$ and $Z$ are subspaces of $X$ such that $X = Y + Z$ and $Z \subset Y^{\perp}$, then $Y^{\perp} = Z$.
proof: Exercise.

name: Closest Point
statement: Let $K$ be a non-empty closed convex subset of a Hilbert space $X$. Then, for every $x \\in X$, there is a unique point $y \\in K$ which is closer to $x$ than any other points of $K$.
proof:
Let

$d = \inf_{z\in K} \|x - z\| \geq 0$

and $y_n \in K$ be a minimizing sequence, i.e.

$\lim_{n\to\infty} d_n = d$,

$d_n = \|x - y_n\|$.

Applying the parallelogram law (1.5) to $\frac{1}{2}(x - y_n)$ and $\frac{1}{2}(x - y_m)$ yields

$\|y_n - y_m\|^2 = \|x - y_n\|^2 + \|x - y_m\|^2 - 2\left\|x - \frac{1}{2}(y_n + y_m)\right\|^2$

Since $K$ is convex, $\frac{1}{2}(y_n + y_m) \in K$ and so $\left\|x - \frac{1}{2}(y_n + y_m)\right\| \geq d$. This and the above implies that $(y_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence. Let $y$ be the limit of this sequence, which belongs to $K$ as $K$ is closed. We then have by the continuity of the norm that $\|x - y\| = \lim \|x - y_n\| = d$, i.e. $y$ minimizes the distance from $x$.

That $y$ is the unique minimizer follows from the same reasoning above. If $y'$ is also a minimizer, we apply the parallelogram law to $\frac{1}{2}(x - y)$ and $\frac{1}{2}(x - y')$ to obtain

$d^2 + \frac{1}{4}\|y - y'\|^2 \leq \left\|x - \frac{1}{2}(y + y')\right\|^2 + \frac{1}{4}\|y - y'\|^2 = \frac{1}{2}(\|x - y\|^2 + \|x - y'\|^2) = d^2$.

This implies that $y = y'$.

name: Projection Theorem
statement: If $Y$ is a closed subspace of a Hilbert space $X$, then $Y$ and $Y^{\\perp}$ are complementary subspaces: $X = Y \\oplus Y^{\\perp}$, i.e. every $x \\in X$ can be decomposed uniquely as a sum of a vector in $Y$ and in $Y^{\\perp}$.
proof:
Certainly $Y \cap Y^{\perp} = \{0\}$. It remains to show that $X = Y + Y^{\perp}$.

Take any $x \in X$ and, since $Y$ is a non-empty closed convex subset of $X$, there is a point $y_0 \in Y$ which is closer to $x$ than any other points of $Y$ by Theorem 1.2.14. To conclude, we show that $x - y_0 \in Y^{\perp}$. Indeed, for all $y \in Y$ and $t \in \mathbb{R}$, we have

$\|x - y_0\|^2 \leq \|x - (y_0 - ty)\|^2 = \|x - y_0\|^2 + 2t \text{Re } \langle x - y_0, y \rangle + t^2 \|y\|^2$.

It follows that $2t \text{Re } \langle x - y_0, y \rangle + t^2 \|y\|^2 \geq 0$ for all $t \in \mathbb{R}$. This implies $\text{Re } \langle x - y_0, y \rangle = 0$. This concludes the proof if the scalar field is real.

If the scalar field is complex, we proceed as before with $t$ replaced by $it$ to show that

$\text{Im } \langle x - y_0, y \rangle = 0$.

name: Closed Subspace Orthogonality
statement: If $Y$ is a closed subspace of a Hilbert space $X$, then $Y = Y^{\\perp\\perp}$.
proof: This follows directly from Theorem 1.2.15. By the Projection theorem, we know that $X = Y \\oplus Y^{\\perp}$. Since $Y$ is a closed subspace, we have $Y \\cap Y^{\\perp} = \\{0\\}$. Now, applying the Projection theorem again to $Y^{\\perp}$ as a closed subspace of $X$, we get $X = Y^{\\perp} \\oplus Y^{\\perp\\perp}$. Comparing these two decompositions of $X$, we must have $Y = Y^{\\perp\\perp}$.

name: Closed Linear Span
statement: The closed linear span of a set $S$ in a Hilbert space $X$ is the smallest closed linear subspace of $X$ containing $S$, i.e. the intersection of all such subspaces.\n\nIt is easy to see that the closed linear span of a set $S$ is the closure of the linear span $\\text{Span } S$.

name: Span Orthogonal Characterization
statement: Let $S$ be a set in a Hilbert space $X$. Then the closed linear span $Y$ of $S$ is $S^{\\perp\\perp}$.
proof: Exercise.

name: Orthonormal Basis
statement: A subset $S$ of a Hilbert space $X$ is called an orthonormal set if $\\|x\\| = 1$ for all $x \\in S$ and $\\langle x, y\\rangle = 0$ for all $x \\neq y \\in S$.\n\n$S$ is called an orthonormal basis (or a complete orthonormal set) for $X$ if $S$ is an orthonormal set and its closed linear span is $X$.

name: Orthonormal Basis Existence
statement: Every Hilbert space contains an orthonormal basis.
proof: We will only give a proof in the case when the Hilbert space $X$ under consideration is separable, i.e. it contains a countable dense subset $S$. The proof in the more general case draws on more sophisticated arguments such as Zorn's lemma.\n\nLabel the elements of $S$ as $y_1, y_2, \\ldots$ Applying the Gram-Schmidt process we obtain an orthonormal set $B = \\{x_1, x_2, \\ldots\\}$ such that, for every $n$, the span of $\\{x_1, \\ldots, x_n\\}$ contains $y_1, \\ldots, y_n$. As $\\overline{S} = X$, this implies that $X = \\overline{\\text{span } B}$, and so $X$ is the closed linear span of $B$.

name: Pythagorean theorem
statement: Let $X$ be a Hilbert space and $S = \\{x_1, x_2, \\ldots, x_m\\}$ be a finite orthonormal set in $X$. For every $x \\in X$, there holds\n\n$\\|x\\|^2 = \\sum_{n=1}^{m} |\\langle x, x_n \\rangle|^2 + \\left\\|x - \\sum_{n=1}^{m} \\langle x, x_n \\rangle x_n \\right\\|^2$.
proof: The proof of this is a direct computation and is omitted.

name: Bessel's inequality
statement: Let $X$ be a Hilbert space and $S = \\{x_1, x_2, \\ldots\\}$ be an orthonormal sequence in $X$. Then, for every $x \\in X$, there holds\n\n$\\sum_{n=1}^{\\infty} |\\langle x, x_n \\rangle|^2 \\leq \\|x\\|^2$.
proof:
This follows directly from Theorem 1.2.21. For any finite subset $\{x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_m\}$ of the orthonormal sequence, we have

$\sum_{n=1}^{m} |\langle x, x_n \rangle|^2 = \|x\|^2 - \left\|x - \sum_{n=1}^{m} \langle x, x_n \rangle x_n \right\|^2 \leq \|x\|^2$

since the norm squared is always non-negative. Taking the limit as $m \to \infty$, we obtain the desired inequality.

name: Orthonormal sequence span
statement:
Let $X$ be a Hilbert space and $S = \{x_1, x_2, \ldots\}$ be an orthonormal sequence in $X$. Then the closed linear span of $S$ consists of vectors of the form

$x = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n x_n$

where the sequence of scalar $(a_1, a_2, \ldots)$ belongs to $\ell^2$. The sum converges in the sense of the Hilbert space norm. Furthermore

$\|x\|^2 = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} |a_n|^2$

(Parseval's identity) and

$a_n = \langle x, x_n \rangle$.
proof: The proof will be done in B4.2 Functional Analysis II.

name: Bounded linear operator
statement:
Let $(X, \|\cdot\|_X)$ and $(Y, \|\cdot\|_Y)$ be normed spaces (always assumed to be over the same field $F$). Then we say that $T: X \to Y$ is a bounded linear operator if $T$ is linear, i.e. $T(x + \alpha\tilde{x}) = Tx + \alpha T\tilde{x}$ for all $x, \tilde{x} \in X$ and $\alpha \in F$, and $T$ has the property that there exists some number $M \in \mathbb{R}$ so that

$\|Tx\|_Y \leq M \|x\|_X$ for all $x \in X$.

We let

$B(X,Y) := \{T: X \to Y \text{ bounded linear operator}\}$

which we always equip with the so called operator norm, which is defined by

$\|T\|_{B(X,Y)} := \inf\{M: \|Tx\|_Y \leq M\|x\|_X \text{ for all } x \in X\}$.

name: Operator continuity equivalence
statement:
Let $(X, \|\cdot\|)$ and $(Y, \|\cdot\|)$ be normed spaces and let $T: X \to Y$ be linear. Then the following are equivalent:

(i) $T$ is Lipschitz continuous,

(ii) $T$ is continuous,

(iii) $T$ is continuous at $x_0 = 0$,

(iv) $T \in B(X,Y)$.
proof:
(i) $\Rightarrow$ (ii) $\Rightarrow$ (iii) are trivial.

(iii) $\Rightarrow$ (iv)

Suppose that $T$ is continuous at $x_0 = 0$. Then there is some $\delta > 0$ such that

$\|Tx\| = \|Tx - T0\| \leq 1$ for $\|x\| = \delta$.

It follows that, for any $x \neq 0$,

$\|Tx\| = \frac{\|x\|}{\delta} T\left(\frac{\delta x}{\|x\|}\right) \leq \frac{\|x\|}{\delta}$.

Clearly, this continues to hold for $x = 0$. Hence $T$ is bounded with $\|T\| \leq \frac{1}{\delta}$.

(iv) $\Rightarrow$ (i)

Let $M \in \mathbb{R}$ be so that $\|Tx\|_Y \leq M\|x\|_X$ holds. Then as $T$ is linear we obtain that for any $x, \tilde{x} \in X$

$\|Tx - T\tilde{x}\| = \|T(x - \tilde{x})\| \leq M \|x - \tilde{x}\|$,

i.e., $T$ is Lipschitz continuous.

name: Isometric Function
statement:
We call a linear function $T : X \rightarrow Y$ isometric if for every $x \in X$ we have $\|T x\| = \|x\|$.

We note that if $T \in B(X, Y)$ is both isometric and bijective, then we have that also $T^{-1}$ is linear and isometric (so in particular a bounded linear operator) as for every $x \in X$

$\|T^{-1}x\| = \|T(T^{-1}x)\| = \|x\|$.

Such a map is called an isometric isomorphism and the spaces $X$ and $Y$ are called isometrically isomorphic, written for short as $X \cong Y$.

name: Integral Operator
statement:
Let $X = C([0, 3])$ as always be equipped with the sup-norm. Given any $k \in C([0, 3] \times [0, 3])$ we map each $x \in X$ to the function $T x : [0, 3] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ that is given by

$T x(t) := \int_0^3 k(s, t)x(s)ds$

where the integral is well defined as the integrand is bounded,

$|k(s, t)x(s)| \leq \|k\|_{\sup} \cdot \|x\|_{\sup}$,

and thus (Lebesgue) integrable over the bounded interval $[0, 3]$. Here the supremum norms of $k$ and $x$ are computed over the corresponding domains, i.e. $[0, 3] \times [0, 3]$ respectively $[0, 3]$.

Claim: $T \in B(X)$.
proof:
T is obviously linear and for any $t \in [0, 3]$ we can bound

$|T x(t)| \leq \int_0^3 |k(s, t)x(s)|ds \leq 3\|k\|_{\sup}\|x\|_{\sup}$.

Provided we show that $T : X \rightarrow X$ is actually well defined, we will thus obtain that $T \in B(X)$ with $\|T\| \leq 3\|k\|_{\sup}$. To prove that $T$ is well defined we have to show that for any function $x \in C([0, 3])$ also $T x$ is continuous on $[0, 3]$, i.e. that for any $t_0 \in [0, 3]$ and any sequence $t_n \rightarrow t_0$ we have $T x(t_n) \rightarrow T x(t_0)$. To this end we set $f_n(s) := k(s, t_n)x(s)$ and $f(s) := k(s, t_0)x(s)$ and observe that

• $f_n(s) \rightarrow f(s)$ for every $s \in [0, 3]$, so in particular $f_n \rightarrow f$ a.e.

• $|f_n| \leq g$ on $[0, 3]$ for the constant function $g := \|k\|_{\sup}\|x\|_{\sup}$ which is of course integrable over the interval $[0, 3]$.

Hence, by the dominated convergence theorem of Lebesgue, we have that

$\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} (T x)(t_n) = \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} \int_0^3 f_n(s)ds \stackrel{DCT}{=} \int_0^3 \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} f_n ds = \int_0^3 f(s)ds = (T x)(t_0)$

as claimed.

name: Matrix Operator Bound
statement: Let $T : \\mathbb{R}^n \\rightarrow \\mathbb{R}^m$ be defined by $T x = Ax$ for some $A \\in M_{m\\times n}(\\mathbb{R})$ where we equip $\\mathbb{R}^n$ and $\\mathbb{R}^m$ with the Euclidean norm. Then $T \\in B(\\mathbb{R}^n, \\mathbb{R}^m)$ and its operator norm is bounded by the Hilbert-Schmidt norm of $A$:\n\n$\\|T\\| \\leq \\|A\\|$.

name: Symmetric Matrix Norm
statement:
For most matrices we have

$\|T\| < \|A\|$

and computing $\|T\|$ can be difficult. For symmetric $n \times n$ matrices however we can easily show (using material from Prelims Linear Algebra) that

$\|T\| = \max\{|\lambda_1|, \ldots .|\lambda_n|\}$,

$\lambda_i$ the eigenvalues of $A$.

name: Completeness of B(X,Y)
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be any normed space and let $(Y, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a Banach space. Then $B(X, Y)$ (equipped with the operator norm) is complete and thus a Banach space.
proof:
Let $(T_n)$ be a Cauchy-sequence in $B(X, Y)$. Then for every $x \in X$ we have that

$\|T_n x - T_m x\| \leq \|T_n - T_m\| \|x\| \rightarrow 0$ as $n,m\rightarrow\infty$

so $(T_n x)$ is a Cauchy sequence in $Y$ and, as $Y$ is complete, thus converges to some element in $Y$ which we call $T x$.

We now show that the resulting map $x \mapsto T x$ is an element of $B(X, Y)$ and $T_n \rightarrow T$ in $B(X, Y)$, i.e. $\|T - T_n\| \rightarrow 0$.

We first note that the linearity of $T_n$ (and (AOL)) implies that also $T$ is linear. Given any $\varepsilon > 0$ we now let $N$ be so that for $m, n \geq N$ we have $\|T_n - T_m\| \leq \varepsilon$. Given any $x \in X$ we thus have

$\|T x - T_n x\| = \|\lim_{m\rightarrow\infty} T_m x - T_n x\| = \lim_{m\rightarrow\infty} \|T_m x - T_n x\| \leq \varepsilon\|x\|$.

Hence $T$ is bounded (as $\|T x\| \leq (\|T_n\| + \varepsilon)\|x\|$ for all $x$) and so an element of $B(X, Y)$ with $\|T - T_n\| \leq \varepsilon$ for all $n \geq N$, so as $\varepsilon > 0$ was arbitrary we obtain that $T_n \rightarrow T$ in the sense of $B(X, Y)$.

name: Composition Bound
statement: The composition $ST$ of two bounded linear operators $S \\in B(Y, Z)$ and $T \\in B(X, Y)$ between normed spaces $X, Y, Z$ is again a bounded linear operator and we have\n\n$\\|ST\\|_{B(X,Z)} \\leq \\|S\\|_{B(Y,Z)} \\|T\\|_{B(X,Y)}$.
proof:
Clearly $ST$ is linear. Given any $x \in X$ we can furthermore bound

$\|ST x\| = \|S(T x)\| \leq \|S\| \|T x\| \leq \|S\| \|T\| \|x\|$

which implies the claim.

name: Convergence of Compositions
statement:
The proposition implies in particular that for sequences $T_n \rightarrow T$ in $B(X, Y)$ and $S_n \rightarrow S$ in $B(Y, Z)$ also

$S_n T_n \rightarrow ST$ in $B(X, Z)$

since

$\|S_n T_n - ST\| \stackrel{\Delta}{\leq} \|(S_n - S)T_n\| + \|S(T_n - T)\| \leq \|S_n - S\|\|T_n\| + \|S\|\|T_n - T\| \rightarrow 0$

where we use in the last step that $\|T_n\|$ is bounded since $T_n$ converges.

name: Exponential Convergence
statement:
Let $X$ be a Banach space and let $A \in B(X)$. Then

$\exp(A) := \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k!} A^k$

converges in $B(X)$ and hence $\exp(A)$ is a well defined element of $B(X)$.
proof:
We know that

$\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \|\frac{1}{k!}A^k\| \leq \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{\|A\|^k}{k!} = \exp(\|A\|) < \infty$,

i.e. that the series converges absolutely. As $X$ is complete and thus, by Theorem 2.2.1, also $B(X)$ is complete we hence obtain from Corollary 1.1.8 that the series converges.

name: Neumann Series
statement: Let $X$ be a Banach space and let $T \\in B(X)$ be so that $\\|T\\| < 1$. Then the operator $\\operatorname{Id} - T$ is invertible with\n\n$(\\operatorname{Id} - T)^{-1} = \\sum_{j=0}^{\\infty} T^j \\in B(X)$.

name: Invertible Operator
statement: An element $T \\in B(X)$ is called invertible (short for invertible in $B(X)$) if there exists $S \\in B(X)$ so that $ST = TS = Id$.\n\nIf we only talk about $T : X \\to X$ being 'invertible as a function between sets', we sometimes say that $T$ is algebraically invertible and that a function $S : X \\to X$ is an algebraic inverse of $T$ if $ST = TS = Id$ (but not necessarily $S \\in B(X)$).

name: Invertibility Perturbation
statement: Let $T \\in B(X)$ be invertible. Then for any $S \\in B(X)$ with $\\|S\\| < \\|T^{-1}\\|^{-1}$ we have that $T - S$ is invertible.
proof: As $T$ is invertible (which by definition means that also $T^{-1} \\in B(X)$) we obtain can write $T - S = T(Id - T^{-1}S)$ and note that $T^{-1}S \\in B(X)$ with $\\|T^{-1}S\\|_{B(X)} \\leq \\|T^{-1}\\|\\|S\\| < 1$. By Lemma 2.2.5 we thus find that $(Id - T^{-1}S)$ is invertible with $(Id - T^{-1}S)^{-1} = \\sum_{j=0}^{\\infty}(T^{-1}S)^j \\in B(X)$ and hence $T - S$ is the composition of two invertible operators and thus invertible, compare also Q.1 on Problem Sheet 2.

name: Norm Equivalence
statement: Any norm $\\| \\cdot \\|$ on $\\mathbb{R}^m$, $m \\in \\mathbb{N}$, is equivalent to the Euclidean norm $\\|x\\|_2 := (\\sum_{i=1}^m x^2_i)^{1/2}$ and hence all norms on $\\mathbb{R}^m$ are equivalent.
proof:
We first remark that the last part of the proposition simply follows from the transitivity of the relation of norms being equivalent, so it remains to show that for any norm $\| \cdot \|$ there exist constants $C_{1,2} \in \mathbb{R}$ so that for every $x \in \mathbb{R}^m$

$\|x\| \leq C_1\|x\|_2$ and $\|x\|_2 \leq C_2\|x\|$.

To get the first inequality we note that for any $x = (x_1, \ldots, x_m) = \sum_{i=1}^m x_ie_i \in \mathbb{R}^m$

$\|x\| \leq \sum_{i=1}^m |x_i| \|e_i\| \leq (\sum_{i=1}^m |x_i|^2)^{1/2}(\sum_{i=1}^m \|e_i\|^2)^{1/2} = C_1\|x\|_2$

where we set $C_1 := (\sum_{i=1}^m \|e_i\|^2)^{1/2}$.

For the proof of the reverse inequality we give two slightly different variants, which are however based on the same core idea and use in particular the Theorem of Heine-Borel in Euclidean space $(\mathbb{R}^m, \| \cdot \|_2)$.

Variant 1 (Using that continuous functions on compact sets achieve their minimum:)
We note that the function $f(x) := \|x\|$ is a Lipschitz-continuous function from $(\mathbb{R}^m, \| \cdot \|_2)$ to $\mathbb{R}$ (though of course not an element of $B(\mathbb{R}^n, \mathbb{R})$ as not linear) as the reverse triangle inequality combined with (3.1) allows us to bound

$|f(x) - f(y)| = |\|x\| - \|y\|| \leq \|x - y\| \leq C_1\|x - y\|_2$.

As the (Euclidean) unit sphere $S = \{x \in \mathbb{R}^n : \|x\|_2 = 1\}$ is a closed and bounded subset of $(\mathbb{R}^n, \| \cdot \|_2)$ and hence by Heine-Borel compact, we know that $f|_S$ achieves its minimum in some point $x^* \in S$. As $\| \cdot \|$ is a norm, we know that $f(x^*) > 0$ and set $C_2 := \frac{1}{f(x^*)}$. With this choice of $C_2$ we then get that for every $x \in X$

$C_2\|x\| = C_2\|x\|_2 \cdot \|\frac{x}{\|x\|_2}\| = C_2\|x\|_2 f(\frac{x}{\|x\|_2}) \geq C_2\|x\|_2 f(x^*) = \|x\|_2$

which gives the reverse inequality claimed above.

Variant 2 (Proof by contradiction) Suppose that there exists no constant $C_2$ so that the inequality $\|x\|_2 \leq C_2\|x\|$ holds true for every $x \in X$. Then we can choose a sequence of elements $x^{(n)} \in \mathbb{R}^m \setminus \{0\}$ so that $\|x^{(n)}\|_2 \geq n\|x^{(n)}\|$. The renormalised sequence $\tilde{x}^{(n)} = \frac{x^{(n)}}{\|x^{(n)}\|_2}$ then consists of elements of the Euclidean unit sphere $S$ which as observed above is compact and thus has a subsequence that converges $\tilde{x}^{(n_j)} \to x \in S$ with respect to the Euclidean norm $\| \cdot \|_2$. As $x \in S$, we know that $x \neq 0$ and thus $\|x\| \neq 0$ which contradicts the fact that

$\|x\| \leq \|x - \tilde{x}^{(n_j)}\| + \|\tilde{x}^{(n_j)}\| \leq C_1\|x - \tilde{x}^{(n_j)}\|_2 + \frac{1}{n_j} \to 0$.

We note that the exact same proof (replacing all $\mathbb{R}$ with $\mathbb{C}$) applies also if the field is $F = \mathbb{C}$ and hence yields that all norms on $\mathbb{C}^m$ are equivalent.

name: Norm Equivalence
statement: Let $X$ be any finite dimensional space. Then any two norm $\\| \\cdot \\|$ and $\\| \\cdot \\|'$ on $X$ are equivalent.
proof:
Let $m = \dim(X)$. Choosing a basis $f_1, \ldots, f_m$ of $X$ we know from Prelims Linear Algebra that the map

$Q : \mathbb{R}^m \ni (\mu_1, \ldots, \mu_m) \mapsto \sum_{i=1}^m \mu_i f_i \in X$

is a linear bijection. Given any two norms $\| \cdot \|_X$ and $\| \cdot \|'_X$ on $X$ we obtain two norms $\| \cdot \|_{\mathbb{R}^m}$ and $\| \cdot \|'_{\mathbb{R}^m}$ on $\mathbb{R}^m$ by defining for every $x \in \mathbb{R}^n$

$\|x\|_{\mathbb{R}^m} := \|Q(x)\|_X$ respectively $\|x\|'_{\mathbb{R}^m} := \|Q(x)\|'_X$.

We note that these norms are chosen so that the maps $Q : (\mathbb{R}^m, \| \cdot \|_{\mathbb{R}^m}) \to (X, \| \cdot \|_X)$ and $Q : (\mathbb{R}^m, \| \cdot \|'_{\mathbb{R}^m}) \to (X, \| \cdot \|'_X)$ are isometric and hence, as they are bijections, so are their inverses (i.e. $Q$ and $Q'$ are isometric isomorphisms). Using that, by Proposition 3.0.1, all norms on $\mathbb{R}^m$ are equivalent and hence that there exist constants $C_{1,2}$ so that

$\|x\|_{\mathbb{R}^m} \leq C_1\|x\|'_{\mathbb{R}^m}$ and $\|x\|'_{\mathbb{R}^m} \leq C_2\|x\|_{\mathbb{R}^m}$

we now conclude that for any $y \in X$

$\|y\|_X = \|Q^{-1}(y)\|_{\mathbb{R}^m} \leq C_1\|Q^{-1}(y)\|'_{\mathbb{R}^m} = C_1\|y\|'_X$

and similarly $\|y\|'_X \leq C_2\|y\|_X$, establishing the equivalence of norms.

name: Boundedness of Linear Maps
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|_X)$ be a finite dimensional normed space and let $(Y, \\| \\cdot \\|_Y)$ be any normed space (not necessarily finite dimensional). Then any linear map $T : X \\to Y$ is an element of $B(X, Y)$, i.e. a bounded linear operator.
proof:
Given any such $T$ we set for every $x \in X$

$\|x\|_T := \|x\|_X + \|Tx\|_Y$.

We can easily check that this defines a norm on the finite dimensional space $X$ which, by the previous theorem, must hence be equivalent to $\| \cdot \|_X$. In particular, there exists a constant $C \in \mathbb{R}$ so that

$\|Tx\|_Y \leq \|x\|_T \leq C\|x\|_X$

which ensures that $T$ is bounded and hence an element of $B(X, Y)$.

name: Homeomorphism to Field
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a finite dimensional normed space. Then $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ is homeomorphic to $\\mathbb{F}^m$, $m = \\dim(X)$ and $\\mathbb{F} = \\mathbb{R}$ respectively $\\mathbb{F} = \\mathbb{C}$, and a linear homeomorphism from $\\mathbb{F}^m$ to $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ can be obtained by choosing any basis $f_1, \\ldots, f_m$ of $X$ and defining $Q : \\mathbb{F}^m \\ni (\\mu_1, \\ldots, \\mu_m) \\to \\sum_{i=1}^{m} \\mu_i f_i \\in X$.
proof: We recall that a map $f : M \\to \\tilde{M}$ between two metric spaces is called a homeomorphism if $f$ is invertible and both $f$ and $f^{-1}$ are continuous. We also recall that the image $f(C)$ of a closed set $C$ under a homeomorphism $f$ is again closed as it can be viewed as the preimage of $C$ under the continuous function $f^{-1}$.\n\nAs we already know from Linear Algebra that $Q$ is a bijection, this corollary immediately follows from Theorem 3.0.3 which implies that the linear maps $Q, Q^{-1}$ are continuous.

name: Completeness of Finite-Dimensional
statement: Every finite dimensional normed space $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ is complete, i.e. a Banach space.
proof:
We first recall from Prelims Analysis and Part A metric space that $\mathbb{F}^n$, $\mathbb{F} = \mathbb{R}$ or $\mathbb{F} = \mathbb{C}$ equipped with the Euclidean norm $\| \cdot \|_2$ is complete and remark that this can be easily proved by showing that a sequence in $\mathbb{R}^n$ converges/is a Cauchy-sequence if and only if all of its components converge/are Cauchy-sequences in $\mathbb{R}$. (We stress that this statement is wrong in infinite dimensional spaces such as the sequence spaces $\ell^p$).

Let now $Q$ be as in (3.2). Given a Cauchy-sequence $(x_n)$ in $X$ we conclude that since $Q^{-1}$ is a bounded linear operator from $(X, \| \cdot \|_X)$ to $(\mathbb{F}^n, \| \cdot \|_2)$ we have

$\|Q^{-1}(x_n) - Q^{-1}(x_m)\|_2 = \|Q^{-1}(x_n - x_m)\|_2 \leq \|Q^{-1}\| \|x_n - x_m\|_X \to 0$ as $n,m\to\infty$,

i.e. that $Q^{-1}(x_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence in $(\mathbb{R}^n, \| \cdot \|_2)$ and therefore converges to some $y$. Setting $x = Q(y)$ we hence obtain that

$\|x_n - x\|_X = \|Q(Q^{-1}(x_n) - y)\|_X \leq \|Q\| \|Q^{-1}(x_n) - y\|_2 \to 0$,

i.e. that the original Cauchy sequence $(x_n)$ in $X$ converges.

name: Closed Finite Subspaces
statement: Every finite dimensional subspace of a normed vector space $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ is complete and hence closed.
proof: This follows immediately from Theorem 3.0.5, which states that every finite dimensional normed space is complete.

name: Non-closed Subspace
statement: Consider $C([0, 2])$ as a subspace of $(L^1([0, 2]), \\| \\cdot \\|_{L^1})$. Then the sequence $(f_n)_{n\\in\\mathbb{N}} \\subset C([0, 2])$ defined by $f_n(t) = \\begin{cases} t^n, & 0 \\leq t \\leq 1 \\\\ 1, & t > 1 \\end{cases}$ is a Cauchy sequence in $L^1([0, 2])$ with limit $f(t) = \\begin{cases} 0, & 0 \\leq t \\leq 1 \\\\ 1, & t > 1 \\end{cases}$ however $f \\notin C([0, 2])$.
proof: At a more abstract level we could also argue as follows: $C([0, 2])$ is a proper subspace of $L^1([0, 1])$ however, as we shall see later, $C([0, 2])$ is dense in $L^1([0, 1])$, so the closure of $C([0, 2])$ in $L^1([0, 1])$ is $\\overline{C([0, 2])}^{L^1} = L^1([0, 1]) \\neq C([0, 2])$.

name: Heine-Borel Equivalence
statement:
Let $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ a normed space. Then the following are equivalent

(1) $\dim(X) < \infty$.

(2) Every subset $Y \subset X$ that is bounded and closed is compact.

(3) The unit sphere $S := \{x \in X : \|x\| = 1\}$ is compact.
proof:
(1) $\Rightarrow$ (2)
Let $Y$ be a closed and bounded set. Then the image of $Y$ under the homeomorphism $Q^{-1} : X \to \mathbb{F}^m$ obtained in Corollary 3.0.4 is also closed and, as $Q^{-1}$ is a bounded linear operator, also bounded and hence by the Theorem of Heine-Borel a compact subset of $\mathbb{R}^m$. Hence $Y = Q(Q^{-1}(Y))$ is the image of a compact set under the continuous function $Q$ and hence itself compact.

(2) $\Rightarrow$ (3):
Is trivial as $S$ is clearly closed and bounded.

(3) $\Rightarrow$ (1):
We argue by contradiction and assume that $S$ is compact but $\dim(X) = \infty$. We may thus choose a sequence of linearly independent elements $y_k \in X$, $k \in \mathbb{N}$. Then the subspace $Y_k := \span\{y_1, \ldots, y_k\} \subsetneq Y_{k+1}$ is finite dimensional, so by Corollary 3.0.6, a closed proper subspace of $Y_{k+1}$. Applying Proposition 3.0.10 with $\varepsilon = \frac{1}{2}$ (viewing $Y_k$ as a subspace of $Y_{k+1}$ instead of $X$) thus gives us a sequence of elements $y_k \in Y_{k+1} \cap S$ with $\dist(y_k, Y_k) \geq \frac{1}{2}$. In particular for every $k > l$ we have $\|y_k - y_l\| \geq \dist(y_k, Y_{l+1}) \geq \dist(y_k, Y_k) \geq \frac{1}{2}$ so no subsequence of $(y_k)$ can be a Cauchy-sequence. Having thus constructed a sequence $(y_k)$ in $S \subset X$ that does not contain a convergent subsequence we conclude that $S$ is not sequentially compact and hence not compact leading to a contradiction.

name: Riesz-Lemma
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a normed vector space and $Y \\subsetneq X$ a closed subspace. Then to any $\\varepsilon > 0$ there exists an element $x \\in S \\subset X$ in the unit sphere so that $\\dist(x, Y) := \\inf\\{\\|x - y\\| : y \\in Y\\} \\geq 1 - \\varepsilon$.
proof:
We can assume without loss of generality that $\varepsilon \in (0, 1)$.

As $Y \neq X$ is closed we know that the set $X \setminus Y$ is open and non-empty, so we can choose some $x^* \in X \setminus Y$ and use that $d := \dist(x^*, Y) > 0$, as $X \setminus Y$ must contain some ball $B_\delta(x)$ which ensures that $d \geq \delta > 0$.

By the definition of the infimum, we can now select $y^* \in Y$ so that $d \leq \|x^* - y^*\| < \frac{d}{1-\varepsilon}$ and claim that $x := \frac{x^*-y^*}{\|x^*-y^*\|}$ has the desired properties. Clearly $\|x\| = 1$, i.e. $x \in S$ as desired, and we furthermore have that

$\dist(x, Y) = \inf_{y\in Y} \|x - y\| = \inf_{y\in Y} \|\frac{x^* - y^*}{\|x^* - y^*\|} - y\| = \inf_{\tilde{y}\in Y} \|\frac{x^*}{\|x^* - y^*\|} - \frac{y^*}{\|x^* - y^*\|} - \tilde{y}\|$

$= \inf_{\hat{y}\in Y} \|\frac{x^*}{\|x^* - y^*\|} - \hat{y}\| = \frac{\dist(x^*, Y)}{\|x^* - y^*\|} \geq 1 - \varepsilon$

where we used twice that $Y$ is a subspace, to replace the infimum over $y \in Y$ first by an infimum over $\tilde{y} = \frac{y^*}{\|x^*-y^*\|} + y$ and then an infimum over $\hat{y}$ which is related to $\tilde{y}$ by $\tilde{y} = \frac{\hat{y}}{\|x^*-y^*\|}$.

name: Dense Subset
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a normed space. Then a subset $D \\subset X$ is dense if its closure $\\overline{D}$ is given by the whole space $X$, i.e. $\\overline{D} = X$.

name: Extension by Density
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|_X)$ be a normed space, let $Y$ be a dense subspace of $X$ (which we equip with the norm of $X$) and let $(Z, \\| \\cdot \\|_Z)$ be a Banach space. Then any $T \\in B(Y, Z)$ has a unique extension $\\tilde{T} \\in B(X, Z)$, i.e. there exists a unique bounded linear operator $\\tilde{T} : X \\to Z$ so that $\\tilde{T} y = T y$ for every $y \\in Y$ and we furthermore have that $\\| \\tilde{T} \\|_{B(X,Z)} = \\|T \\|_{B(Y,Z)}$.
proof:
Let $x \in X$ be any element. Then as $Y$ is dense there exists a sequence $y_n$ of elements of $Y$ so that $y_n \to x$.

Claim: $T y_n$ converges and the limit $z = \lim_{n\to\infty} T y_n$ depends only on $x$ and not on the chosen sequence $y_n$.

Once proven, this claim allows us define $\tilde{T} x := \lim_{n\to\infty} T y_n$ to obtain a well defined map $\tilde{T} : X \to Z$. This map will be linear as $T$ is linear, as we can interchange limits and addition/scalar multiplication and know that the obtained limit is independent of the chosen approximating sequence. Furthermore

$\| \tilde{T} x\|_Z = \lim_{n\to\infty} \|T y_n\|_Z \leq \|T \| \lim_{n\to\infty} \|y_n\|_X = \|T \|\|x\|_X$

so that $\tilde{T} \in B(X, Z)$ with $\|T \| \geq \| \tilde{T} \|$. The reverse inequality follows from the definition of the operator norm, as

$\| \tilde{T} \|_{B(X,Z)} = \sup_{x\in X,\|x\|_X =1} \| \tilde{T} x\|_Z \geq \sup_{y\in Y,\|y\|_X =1} \| \tilde{T} y\|_Z = \|T \|_{B(Y,Z)}.$

Hence, once the claim is proven, we obtain the desired extension which, by Lemma 4.1.4, is furthermore unique.

It thus remains to prove the claim. To this end we remark that if $y_n \to x$ then $(y_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence and hence also

$\|T y_n - T y_m\|_Z \leq \|T \|\|y_n - y_m\| \to 0$ as $n,m\to\infty$.

So $(T y_n)$ is a Cauchy sequence in the Banach space $Z$ and must thus converge to some limit $z$. To prove that the limit does not depend on the choice of the sequence of elements of $Y$ that approximate $x$, let $\tilde{y}_n$ be any alternative sequence in $Y$ that converges to $x$. Then the argument above implies that $T \tilde{y}_n$ converges to some limit $\tilde{z}$ and one way to see that $z = \tilde{z}$ is to consider a third sequence $\hat{y}_n \to x$ chosen as $\hat{y}_n = y_n$ for $n$ odd and $\hat{y}_n = \tilde{y}_n$ for $n$ even. Then also $T \hat{y}_n$ must converge to a limit $\hat{z}$ which must agree with the limit of both of the subsequences $T \hat{y}_{2n}$ and $T \hat{y}_{2n+1}$, i.e. we must have that $z = \hat{z} = \tilde{z}$ which establishes the claim and thus completes the proof of the theorem.

name: Operator Equality
statement:
Let $(X, \| \cdot \|_X)$ be a normed space, $D \subset X$ a dense subset and let $(Z, \| \cdot \|_Z)$ be a normed space. Then for operators $T, S \in B(X, Z)$ we have

$T |_D = S|_D \Leftrightarrow T = S$.

In particular, the only element $T \in B(X, Z)$ with $T |_D = 0$ is $T = 0$.
proof: We can prove the non-trivial direction \
Rightarrow$\\: s follows: For any $x \\in X$ we can choose a sequence $d_n \\to x$ with $d_n \\in D$ to conclude that since both $T$ and $S$ are continuous\n\n$T x = \\lim_{n\\to\\infty} T d_n = \\lim_{n\\to\\infty} Sd_n = Sx$.

name: Point Separation
statement: We say that a subset $D \\subset C(K)$ separates points if for all $p, q \\in K$ with $p \\neq q$ there exists a function $g \\in D$ so that $g(p) \\neq g(q)$.

name: Linear Sublattice
statement: A subspace $L \\subset C(K)$ is called a linear sublattice if\n\n$f, g \\in L \\Rightarrow \\max(f, g) \\in L$ and $\\min(f, g) \\in L$

name: Stone-Weierstrass-Theorem, lattice form
statement:
Let $K \subset \mathbb{R}^n$ be a compact set and let $C(K)$ be the space of continuous real-valued functions on $K$ which is equipped with the sup-norm. Let $L$ be a subspace of $C(K)$ which is such that

(i) $L$ is a linear sublattice,

(ii) $L$ contains the constant functions, and

(iii) $L$ separates points in $K$.

Then $L$ is dense in $C(K)$.
proof:
Fix $f \in C(K)$ and $\varepsilon > 0$. We would like to construct $g \in L$ such that $\|f - g\|_{\sup} \leq \varepsilon$. Fix some point $p$ for the moment. By Remark 4.2.2, for any $q \in K$, there exists $f_{p,q} \in L$ such that $f_{p,q}(p) = f(p)$ and $f_{p,q}(q) = f(q)$. Let $U^{\varepsilon}_{p,q} = (f - f_{p,q})^{-1}((- \varepsilon, \varepsilon)) \subset K$ so that $|f - f_{p,q}| < \varepsilon$ on $U^{\varepsilon}_{p,q}$.

Observe that $\{U^{\varepsilon}_{p,q}\}_{q \in K}$ is an open cover of $K$ so we can find finitely many points $q_1, \ldots, q_m$ (allowed to depend on the fixed point $p \in K$) so that $K = \bigcup_{i=1}^{m} U^{\varepsilon}_{p,q_i}$. On the sets $U^{\varepsilon}_{p,q_i}$ we have $|f - f_{p,q_i}| < \varepsilon$ and hence in particular $f_{p,q_i} < f + \varepsilon$. Defining $g_p := \min(f_{p,q_1}, \ldots f_{p,q_m})$ we hence obtain a function $g_p \in L$ which satisfies $g_p < f + \varepsilon$ on all of $K$ and is furthermore so that $g_p(p) = f(p)$ as all functions $f_{p,q}$ have the property that $f_{p,q}(p) = f(p)$.

Our construction above gives a good upper bound for $g_p - f$, but no lower bound. To obtain both a good upper bound and a good lower bound, we apply more or less the same procedure to $g_p$, but now letting $p$ vary. Let $V^{\varepsilon}_p = (f - g_p)^{-1}((- \varepsilon, \varepsilon))$ so that $|g_p - f| < \varepsilon$ on $V^{\varepsilon}_p$.

Again $\{V^{\varepsilon}_p\}_{p \in K}$ is an open cover of $K$, and so has a finite subcover $K = \bigcup_{i=1}^{k} V_{p_i}$. Set $g := \max\{g_{p_1}, \ldots, g_{p_k}\}$, which is in $L$ as $L$ is a sublattice. As $g$ is the maximum of functions that satisfy $g_{p_i} < f + \varepsilon$ on all of $K$ we have of course still $g < f + \varepsilon$ on $K$, but now know additionally that for every $x \in K$ there is some $i$ so that $x \in V_{p_i}$ and hence $g(x) \geq g_{p_i}(x) > f(x) - \varepsilon$. Combined we thus obtain that the element $g \in L$ that we constructed satisfies $\|f - g\|_{\sup} < \varepsilon$. As $\varepsilon > 0$ and $f \in C(K)$ were arbitrary this completes the proof that $L$ is dense in $C(K)$.

name: Weierstrass Approximation Theorem
statement: Let $K \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ be compact. Then the space of polynomials is dense in $C(K)$, i.e. for every $f \\in C(K)$ there exists a sequence of polynomials $p_n$ on $K$ so that $p_n \\to f$ in the sense of $(C(K), \\| \\cdot \\|_{\\sup})$, i.e. uniformly.
proof: We note that the space of polynomials trivially contains the constant functions and also separates points (for this already the linear functions would be sufficient). It has furthermore the extra structure of being a subalgebra of the algebra of continuous functions. By Theorem 4.2.8 (Stone-Weierstrass Theorem, subalgebra form), any subalgebra of $C(K)$ which separates points is dense in $C(K)$. Therefore, the space of polynomials is dense in $C(K)$.

name: Subalgebra
statement:
A subspace $A \subset C(K)$ is a subalgebra if $A$ contains the constant functions and

$f, g \in A \Rightarrow f g \in A$

where $(f g)(x) = f(x)g(x)$ is obtained by pointwise multiplication.

name: Stone-Weierstrass Theorem, subalgebra form
statement: Let $A \\subset C(K)$ be a subalgebra of $C(K)$ which separates points. Then $A$ is dense in $C(K)$.
proof: Given a subalgebra $A$ as in the theorem we can easily check that $\\overline{A}$ is also a subalgebra and hence, by Proposition 4.2.9, $\\overline{A}$ is a linear sublattice. As $A$ contains the constant functions and separates points the same holds true also for $\\overline{A}$ so we may apply the sublattice version of the Theorem of Stone Weierstrass (Theorem 4.2.4) to conclude that $\\overline{A}$ is dense in $C(K)$, so $\\overline{A} = C(K)$. Hence $A$ is dense in $C(K)$.

name: Closed Subalgebra Property
statement: If $A \\subset C(K)$ is a subalgebra of $C(K)$ that is closed then $A$ is a linear sublattice.
proof:
We only need to prove that if $f \in A$ then also $|f| \in A$. As $A$ is an algebra and $|f| = \sqrt{f^2}$, we only need to prove that if $g \in A$ and $g \geq 0$, then $\sqrt{g} \in A$.

Let us suppose in the first instant that $g > \delta > 0$ for some small $\delta \in (0, 1)$. By scaling, we may also suppose that $g < 2 - \delta$. Then the function $h = 1 - g$ satisfies $|h| \leq 1 - \delta$. Note that $x := 1 - \sqrt{g}$ satisfies

$(1 - x)^2 = g = 1 - h \Leftrightarrow x = \frac{1}{2}(h + x^2)$.

Thus, we only need to show that this fixed point equation is solvable for $x \in A$.

Indeed, let $T(a) = \frac{1}{2}(h + a^2)$ and $B = \{a \in A : |a| \leq 1 - \delta\}$ (which is a complete metric space). By triangle inequality, $T$ maps $B$ into itself. Moreover, it is also a contraction:

$|T(a) - T(b)| = \frac{1}{2}|a + b||a - b| \leq (1 - \delta)|a - b| \Rightarrow \|T(a) - T(b)\| \leq (1 - \delta)\|a - b\|$.

By the contraction mapping theorem, $T$ has a fixed point in $B$, which is our desired $x \in B \subset A$.

In the general case when we only know that $g \geq 0$, the above shows that $(g + 1/k)^{1/2} \in A$ for all $k > 0$. Therefore, $\sqrt{g}$, being the uniform limit of $((g + 1/k)^{1/2})$, also belongs to $A$ (as $A$ is closed).

name: Weierstrass Application
statement:
We claim that the only continuous real valued function $f \in C[0, 1]$ for which

$(\star)$

$\int_0^1 f(t)t^n dt = 0$ for every $n \in \mathbb{N}$

is the zero function.
proof: To see this, we let $X = C[0, 1]$ (as always equipped with the sup norm) and we note that any function $f \\in C[0, 1]$ induces a bounded linear functional $F \\in X^* = B(X, \\mathbb{R})$ defined by $F(x) = \\int_0^1 f(t)x(t)dt$, where we note that $F$ is bounded since $|Fx| \\leq \\|f\\|_{\\sup}\\|x\\|_{\\sup}$, so $\\|F\\|_{X^*} \\leq \\|f\\|_{\\sup}$. If $f$ satisfies $(\\star)$ then, by linearity, $F(p) = 0$ for every polynomial. Since the polynomials are dense in $X$ by Theorem 4.2.6, we can thus apply Theorem 4.1.3 to obtain that $F = 0$, in particular $F(f) = \\int f^2(t)dt = 0$. But as $f^2 \\geq 0$ this implies that $f^2 = 0$ a.e. and so as $f$ is continuous indeed $f = 0$.

name: Density of Smooth Functions
statement: For any $1 \\leq p < \\infty$ and any compact set $K \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ the space $C^\\infty(K)$ of smooth functions is dense in $L^p(K)$.
proof:
The proof of this result is non-examinable (though the result and its applications are examinable), and we only sketch the proof to introduce the important concept of mollifying an integrable function to obtain a smooth function which is a good approximation to the given (in general not even continuous) function.

We let $\phi: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}$ be defined by

$\phi(x) := c\begin{cases} \exp(-\frac{1}{1-|x|^2}), & |x| < 1 \\ 0, & \text{else} \end{cases}$

where $c > 0$ is chosen so that $\int_{\mathbb{R}^n} \phi(x)dx = 1$ and set $\phi_\varepsilon(x) := \frac{1}{\varepsilon^n} \phi(\frac{x}{\varepsilon})$. These smooth functions $\phi_\varepsilon$ (which are often called 'mollification kernels' or a family of 'standard mollifiers') have $\int_{\mathbb{R}^n} \phi_\varepsilon = 1$ and are zero outside of $B_\varepsilon(0)$. One can get a sequence $f_\varepsilon$ of smooth functions that approximates a given $f \in L^p(K)$ as follows: We extend $f$ by zero outside of $K$ to get a function that is defined on all of $\mathbb{R}^n$ and then set

$f_\varepsilon := \phi_\varepsilon * f, \text{ i.e. define } f_\varepsilon(x) := \int_{\mathbb{R}} \phi(x - y)f(y)dy.$

Then one can easily check that $f_\varepsilon \in C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n)$ with derivatives $D^\alpha f_\varepsilon = (D^\alpha \phi_\varepsilon) * f$ (follows from the differentiation theorem from Part A Integration) and one can indeed prove that $f_\varepsilon \to f$ in $L^p$ (though this proof requires more care and uses properties of $L^p$ functions that we do not require elsewhere in the course).

name: Separable Space
statement: A normed space $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|)$ is called separable if there exists a countable set $D \\subset X$ which is dense. A space which is not separable is called inseparable.

name: Separability Preservation
statement: (i) Let $X$ be a vector space and let $\\|\\cdot\\|$ and $\\|\\cdot\\|'$ be two norms on $X$ that are equivalent. Then $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|)$ and $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|')$ are either both separable or both inseparable.\n\n(ii) Let $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ and $(Y, \\|\\cdot\\|_Y)$ be two normed spaces which are isometrically isomorphic, i.e. so that there exists a linear bijection $i: X \\to Y$ so that $\\|i(x)\\|_Y = \\|x\\|_X$ for all $x \\in X$. Then $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ and $(Y, \\|\\cdot\\|_Y)$ are either both separable or both inseparable.
proof:
As equivalent norms lead to the same notion of convergent sequences we obtain that a set $D \subset X$ is dense in $(X, \|\cdot\|)$ if and only if it is dense in $(X, \|\cdot\|')$. Hence (i) follows.

Similarly, to obtain (ii) we note that if $D \subset X$ is dense and if $i: X \to Y$ is an isometric isomorphism then $\tilde{D} := i(D) \subset Y$ is dense as for any $y \in Y$ we can choose $d_n \in D$ so that $d_n \to x := i^{-1}(y)$ and thus get a sequence $\tilde{d}_n = i(d_n) \in \tilde{D}$ that converges to $y$ since

$\|y - \tilde{d}_n\|_Y = \|i(x) - i(d_n)\|_Y = \|i(x - d_n)\|_Y = \|x - d_n\|_X \to 0$ as $n \to \infty$.

We also recall from prelims that

$\bullet$ $\mathbb{Q} \subset \mathbb{R}$ and $\mathbb{Q} + i\mathbb{Q} \subset \mathbb{C}$ are dense, so both $F = \mathbb{R}$ and $F = \mathbb{C}$ are separable

$\bullet$ Finite products $A_1 \times \ldots \times A_n$ and countable unions $\cup_{j\in\mathbb{N}} A_j$ of countable sets are countable.

name: Finite Dimensional Separability
statement: Every finite dimensional normed space $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ is separable.
proof:
For simplicity of notation we will carry out this proof just for real normed spaces and remark that the exact same proof, with $\mathbb{R}$ replaced by $\mathbb{C}$ and $\mathbb{Q}$ replaced by $\mathbb{Q} + i\mathbb{Q}$ applies in the complex case.

We first show that $\mathbb{R}^n$ equipped with the $1$-norm is separable. Indeed, given any $x = (x_1, \ldots, x_n) \in \mathbb{R}^n$ and any $\varepsilon > 0$ we can use that $\mathbb{Q}$ is dense in $\mathbb{R}$ to choose $q_i \in \mathbb{Q}$ so that $|x_i - q_i| < \frac{\varepsilon}{n}$ and hence $\|x - (q_1, \ldots, q_n)\| < \varepsilon$. As $\mathbb{Q}^n$ is countable we thus get that $(\mathbb{R}^n, \|\cdot\|_1)$ is separable. As every other norm $\|\cdot\|$ on $\mathbb{R}^n$ is equivalent to $\|\cdot\|_1$ we thus get that also $(\mathbb{R}^n, \|\cdot\|)$ is separable thanks to Lemma 5.0.2.

Given any other real finite dimensional vector space $(X, \|\cdot\|_X)$ we let $Q: \mathbb{R}^n \to X$ be the isomorphism introduced in (3.2) and note that $Q$ is an isometric isomorphism if we equip $\mathbb{R}^n$ with the norm $\|x\| := \|Qx\|_X$. The separability of $(X, \|\cdot\|)$ thus follows from the separability of $(\mathbb{R}^n, \|\cdot\|)$ and Lemma 5.0.2.

name: Inseparability of Spaces
statement: The sequence space $(\\ell^\\infty(F), \\|\\cdot\\|_\\infty)$ and the function spaces $L^\\infty(\\Omega)$, $\\Omega \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ any non-empty open set, are inseparable.
proof: We recall that the set $A := \\{a = (a_1, a_2, \\ldots) : a_i \\in \\{0, 1\\}\\}$ is uncountable and note that for this subset of $\\ell^\\infty$ the distance of any two elements $a \\neq \\tilde{a}$ is $\\|a - \\tilde{a}\\|_\\infty = 1$.\n\nLet now $D$ be any dense subset of $\\ell^\\infty$. Then given any $a \\in A$ there must be an element $d_a \\in D$ so that $\\|d_a - a\\| < \\frac{1}{2}$ and we define a function $f : A \\to D$ by assigning to each $a$ such an element $d_a$. We note that $d_a = d_{\\tilde{a}}$ implies that $\\|a - \\tilde{a}\\| = \\|a - d_a + d_{\\tilde{a}} - \\tilde{a}\\| \\leq \\|a-d_a\\|+\\|\\tilde{a}-d_{\\tilde{a}}\\| < 1$ and hence that $a = \\tilde{a}$ so this map is injective. Since $A$ is uncountable, we thus obtain that any dense subset of $\\ell^\\infty$ is uncountable. Hence $\\ell^\\infty$ is inseparable.

name: Density Transitivity
statement: Let $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ be a normed space, $Y \\subset X$ a subspace (which we equip as always with the same norm $\\|\\cdot\\|_X$). Suppose that $D \\subset (Y, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ is dense and that $Y \\subset (X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ is dense. Then also $D \\subset X$ is dense.
proof: This follows from a simple $\\varepsilon/2$ argument: Given $x \\in X$ and $\\varepsilon > 0$ we use that $Y$ is dense in $X$ to choose $y \\in Y$ so that $\\|x - y\\|_X < \\frac{\\varepsilon}{2}$ and then use that $D \\subset Y$ is dense to choose $d \\in D$ with $\\|d - y\\|_X < \\frac{\\varepsilon}{2}$. Therefore, $\\|x - d\\|_X \\leq \\|x - y\\|_X + \\|y - d\\|_X < \\frac{\\varepsilon}{2} + \\frac{\\varepsilon}{2} = \\varepsilon$, which shows that $D$ is dense in $X$.

name: Countable Span Density
statement: Let $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|)$ be a normed space and suppose that there exists a countable set $S$ so that $\\text{span}(\\bar{S})$ is dense in $X$. Then $X$ is separable.
proof:
We prove that if $\text{span}(\bar{S})$ is dense, then also the set

$Y := \left\{\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_i s_i : a_i \in \mathbb{Q}, s_i \in S, N \in \mathbb{N}\right\}$

of rational linear combinations of elements of the set $S$ is dense in $X$.

Indeed given any $x \in X$ and any $\varepsilon > 0$ we can first use that $\text{span}(\bar{S})$ is dense in $X$ to determine $\bar{s}_j \in \bar{S}$ and $a_j \in \mathbb{R}$, $j = 1, \ldots, N$, so that $\|x - \sum_{j=1}^N a_j \bar{s}_j\| < \varepsilon/3$. In a second step we can now use that every element in the closure $\bar{S}$ of a set can be approximated by elements of the set $S$ to determine $s_j \in S$ so that for every $j$ we have $|a_j|\|s_j - \bar{s}_j\| < \frac{\varepsilon}{3N}$. Finally, we use that $\mathbb{Q}$ is dense in $\mathbb{R}$ to determine rational numbers $b_i$ so that for every $j$ also $|a_j - b_j| \cdot \|s_j\| < \frac{\varepsilon}{3N}$. All in all we hence obtain an element $y = \sum_{j=1}^N b_j s_j$ of $Y$ for which

$\|x - y\| \leq \|x - \sum_{j=1}^N a_j \bar{s}_j\| + \|\sum_{j=1}^N (a_j \bar{s}_j - b_j s_j)\| < \varepsilon/3 + \sum_{j=1}^N \|a_j \bar{s}_j - a_j s_j + a_j s_j - b_j s_j\|$
$\leq \varepsilon/3 + \sum_{j=1}^N |a_j|\|s_j - \bar{s}_j\| + \sum_{j=1}^N |a_j - b_j|\|s_j\| < \varepsilon$.

To conclude the proof of the proposition it is thus enough to show that $Y$ is countable. Writing $S = \{s_1, s_2, \ldots\}$ we obtain a surjective map $f : A \to S$ from the set

$A := \bigcup_{N \in\mathbb{N}} \{(a_1, \ldots) : a_k \in \mathbb{Q} \text{ and } a_k = 0 \text{ for every } k \geq N + 1\}$

of finite rational sequences to $Y$ by defining $s(a) := \sum_j a_j s_j$ for $a \in A$ (we note that this sum is well defined as only finitely many terms are non-zero). As $A$ is the countable union of sets that are bijective to $\mathbb{Q}^N$, we know that $A$ is countable and hence that also $Y$ is countable.

name: Separability of Spaces
proof:
Proof of (i):
The set of monomials $\{x^\alpha = x_1^{\alpha_1} \ldots x_n^{\alpha_n}, \alpha \in \mathbb{N}_0^n\}$ is countable and by Weierstrass's Theorem we know that its span, i.e., the space of polynomials, is dense in $C(K)$. By Proposition 5.0.6 we thus get that $C(K)$ is separable.

Proof of (ii): We let $Y := \text{span}(S)$ where the countable set $S = \{e^{(k)}, k \in \mathbb{N}\}$ consists of all sequences $e^{(k)}$ for which the $e_j^{(k)} = \delta_j^k$. Given any element $x = (x_1, \ldots) \in \ell^p$ we can now use that since $\sum_{j=1}^\infty |x_j|^p$ converges, we obtain that the cut-off sequences $x^{(k)} := (x_1, \ldots, x_k, 0, 0, \ldots)$ approximate $x$ in the sense of $\ell^p$, namely $\|x - x^{(k)}\|_{\ell^p} = (\sum_{j\geq k+1} |x_j|^p)^{1/p} \to 0$ as $k \to \infty$. We thus conclude that $Y$ is dense in $\ell^p$ and thus obtain from Proposition 5.0.6 that $\ell^p$ is separable.

Proof of (iii), Variant 1 (using Theorem 4.3.1):
From Theorem 4.3.1 we know that $C^\infty(K)$ is dense in $L^p(K)$ and hence in particular that $C(K)$ is dense in $L^p(K)$. We now claim that $C(K)$ is separable also when equipped with the $L^p$ norm instead of the usual sup-norm. Indeed as $\|f\|_{L^p} \leq (\int_K \|f\|^p)^{1/p} \leq L^n(K)^{1/p}\|f\|_{\sup}$ we know that if a sequence $f_n$ converges to some element $f \in C(K)$ in the usual sense of the sup-norm, then also $\|f_n - f\|_{L^p} \leq L^n(K)^{1/p}\|f_n - f\|_{\sup} \to 0$. Hence any set $D \subset C(K)$ that is dense with respect to the sup-norm, will also be dense with respect to the $L^p$ norm. In particular the set of polynomials is dense also in $(C(K), \|\cdot\|_{L^p})$. Combined with the density of $C(K) \subset L^p(K)$ and Lemma 5.0.5 we thus conclude that the space of polynomials is dense in $L^p(K)$. The claim that $L^p$ is separable hence again follows from Proposition 5.0.6 and the fact that the space of polynomials is spanned by the countable set $\{x^\alpha, \alpha \in \mathbb{N}_0^n\}$ of monomials.

Proof of (iii), Variant 2 (using density of step functions) for $K = [a, b]$:
We use without proof the fact that the space of step functions, that is finite linear combinations of characteristic functions of intervals, is dense in $L^p$. We then note that given any interval $[c, d] \subset [a, b]$ with real endpoints, we can choose $c_n, d_n \in \mathbb{Q}$ so that $c_n \to c$ and $d_n \to d$ and that this guarantees that $\chi_{[c_i,d_i]} \to \chi_{[c,d]}$ in $L^p$ as $\|\chi_{[c,d]} - \chi_{[c_i,d_i]}\| \leq (|c - c_i|+|d - d_i|)^{1/p} \to 0$. Hence also the span of all characteristic functions $\chi_{[c,d]}$ of intervals with rational endpoints is dense in $L^p$ and as the set of such functions $\{\chi_{[c,d]}, c < d, c, d \in \mathbb{Q}\}$ is countable we obtain from Proposition 5.0.6 that $L^p([a, b])$ is separable.

name: Subspace Separability
statement: Let $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ be a separable normed space and let $Y$ be a subspace of $X$. Then also $(Y, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ is separable.
proof:
As $X$ is separable there exists a countable dense subset $D_X := \{x_k, k \in \mathbb{N}\} \subset X$. To prove that $Y$ is separable, we now need to determine a subset of $Y$ that is dense in $Y$. To this end, we use that (by the definition of the infimum) we can choose for any $k, n \in \mathbb{N}$ an element $y_{k,n} \in Y$ so that

$\|x_k - y_{k,n}\| \leq \text{dist}(x_k, Y) + \frac{1}{n} = \inf_{y\in Y} \|x_k - y\| + \frac{1}{n}$

Note that $D := \{y_{k,n}, k, n \in \mathbb{N}\}$ is countable. We claim that $D \subset Y$ is dense. Indeed, given any $y \in Y$ and any $\varepsilon > 0$ we can first use that $D_X$ is dense in $X$ to find some $x_k$ with $\|y - x_k\| < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}$, which we note implies in particular that $\text{dist}(x_k, Y) < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}$. Choosing $n$ large enough so that $\frac{1}{n} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3}$ we hence know that $\|x_k - y_{k,n}\| < \text{dist}(x_k, Y) + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} < \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{\varepsilon}{3} = \frac{2\varepsilon}{3}$ and hence get that

$\|y - y_{k,n}\| \leq \|y - x_k\| + \|x_k - y_{k,n}\| < \frac{\varepsilon}{3} + \frac{2\varepsilon}{3} = \varepsilon$.

This proves that $D$ is dense in $Y$, and since $D$ is countable, $Y$ is separable.

name: Dual Space
statement:
Let $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ be a normed space. Then the dual space of $X$ is defined as

$X^* := B(X, F)$ equipped with the operator norm

$\|f \|_{X^*} := \inf\{M : |f(x)| \leq M \|x\| \text{ for every } x \in X\}$,

where as always $F = R$ if $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ is a real normed space, respectively $F = C$ for complex spaces.

name: Hahn-Banach Extension
statement: Let $X$ be a (real or complex) normed space, $Y \\subset X$ a subspace and let $f \\in Y^*$ be any given element of the dual space of $Y$. Then there exists an extension $F \\in X^*$ of $f$, i.e. an element $F$ of $X^*$ so that $F|_Y = f$, so that\n\n$\\|F\\|_{X^*} = \\|f\\|_{Y^*}$.

name: Sublinear Functional
statement: Let $X$ be a real vector space. Then $p : X \\to R$ is called sublinear if for every $x, y \\in X$ and every $\\lambda \\geq 0$ we have that\n\n$p(x + y) \\leq p(x) + p(y)$ and $p(\\lambda x) = \\lambda p(x)$.

name: Hahn-Banach Sublinear
statement:
Let $X$ be a real vector space, $Y \subset X$ a subspace and $p : X \to R$ sublinear. Suppose that $f : Y \to R$ is a linear functional with the property that

$f(y) \leq p(y)$ for all $y \in Y$.

Then there exists a linear extension $F : X \to R$ so that

$F(x) \leq p(x)$ for all $x \in X$.

name: 1-step Extension
statement:
Let $X$ be a real vector space, $p : X \to R$ sublinear and let $Y, \tilde{Y}$ be subspaces of $X$ which are so that there exists some $x_0 \in X$ so that

$\tilde{Y} = \text{span}(Y \cup \{x_0\})$.

Then for any linear $f : Y \to R$ for which $f(y) \leq p(y)$ for all $y \in Y$ there exists a linear extension $\tilde{f} : \tilde{Y} \to R$ so that

$\tilde{f}(\tilde{y}) \leq p(\tilde{y})$ for all $\tilde{y} \in \tilde{Y}$.
proof:
If $x_0 \in Y$ then the claim is trivial as $\tilde{Y} = Y$. So suppose instead that $x_0 \notin Y$. Then we can write every $\tilde{y} \in \tilde{Y}$ uniquely as

$\tilde{y} = y + \lambda x_0$ for some $\lambda \in R$

so given any number $r \in R$ we obtain a well defined linear map $\tilde{f}_r : \tilde{Y} \to R$ if we set

$\tilde{f}_r(y + \lambda x_0) := f(y) + \lambda r$ for every $y \in Y$ and $\lambda \in R$

and note that $\tilde{f}_r|_Y = f$ no matter how $r$ is chosen. We now need to show that we can choose $r$ so that this function $\tilde{f}$ has the required property that $\tilde{f}_r(\tilde{y}) \leq p(\tilde{y})$ for all $\tilde{y} \in \tilde{Y}$, which is equivalent to

$\lambda r \leq p(y + \lambda x_0) - f(y)$ for all $y \in Y, \lambda \in R$.

We first note that for $\lambda = 0$ this is trivially true no matter how $r$ is chosen as by assumption $f \leq p$ on $Y$.

For $\lambda > 0$ the above inequality holds true if and only if

$r \leq \frac{1}{\lambda}(p(y + \lambda x_0) - f(y)) = p(\frac{1}{\lambda}y + x_0) - f(\frac{1}{\lambda}y)$

for all $y \in Y$ or equivalently, setting $v = \frac{1}{\lambda}y$ and using that $Y$ is a vector space, if and only if

$r \leq \inf_{v \in Y}(p(v + x_0) - f(v))$.

For $\lambda < 0$ we write $\lambda = -|\lambda|$ to rewrite the inequality as $-|\lambda|r \leq p(y - |\lambda|x_0) - f(y)$. We hence obtain that the inequality is satisfied for all $\lambda < 0$ and $y \in Y$ if and only if

$r \geq -|\lambda|^{-1}(p(y - |\lambda|x_0) - f(y)) = f(|\lambda|^{-1}y) - p(|\lambda|^{-1}y - x_0)$,

i.e. if and only if $r$ is chosen so that

$r \geq \sup_{w \in Y}(f(w) - p(w - x_0))$.

For $\tilde{f}_r$ to be the required extension we thus need to choose $r$ so that both inequalities hold, which is possible provided

$\inf_{v \in Y}(p(v + x_0) - f(v)) \geq \sup_{w \in Y}(f(w) - p(w - x_0))$.

However this easily follows since for any $v, w \in Y$ we have that

$(p(v + x_0) - f(v)) - (f(w) - p(w - x_0)) = p(v + x_0) + p(w - x_0) - f(v + w)$

$\geq p(v + w) - f(v + w) \geq 0$

where we use the sublinearity of $p$ in the second and the assumption that $f \leq p$ on $Y$ in the last step.

name: Norm-Attaining Functional
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a normed space. Then for any $x \\in X \\setminus \\{0\\}$ there exists an element $f \\in X^*$ with $\\|f\\| = 1$ so that $f(x) = \\|x\\|$.
proof: Let $Y = \\text{span}(x)$ and define $g(\\lambda x) = \\lambda \\|x\\|$ for $\\lambda \\in F$. Then $g \\in Y^*$ with $\\|g\\| = 1$ and hence $g$ has an extension $f \\in X^*$ with $\\|f\\| = 1$ and $f(x) = g(x) = \\|x\\|$.

name: Dual Norm Characterization
statement:
Let $(X, \| \cdot \|)$, $X \neq \{0\}$, be a normed space. Then

(i) For every $x \in X$ we have $\|x\|_X = \sup_{f \in X^*, \|f\|_{X^*} = 1} |f(x)|$.

(ii) For every $f \in X^*$ we have $\|f\|_{X^*} = \sup_{x \in X, \|x\|_X = 1} |f(x)|$.
proof: We already observed that the second statement is an easy consequence of the definition of the operator norm on $X$. For the proof of (i) we observe that Proposition 6.3.1 implies that $\\|x\\|_X \\leq \\sup_{f \\in X^*, \\|f\\|_{X^*} = 1} |f(x)|$ while the reverse inequality is trivially true since $|f(x)| \\leq \\|f\\| \\|x\\| = \\|x\\|$ for every $f \\in X^*$ with $\\|f\\| = 1$.\n\nWe note that while the supremum in (ii) is in general not achieved, Proposition 6.3.1 implies that the supremum in (i) is always achieved.

name: Point Separation
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a normed space. Then for any two elements $x \\neq y$ of $X$ there exists an element $f \\in X^*$ so that $f(x) \\neq f(y)$.
proof: This corollary follows as Proposition 6.3.1 allows us to choose $f \\in X^*$ so that $f(x-y) = \\|x-y\\| \\neq 0$.

name: Kernel Codimension
statement: Let $X$ be a normed space and let $f: X \\to F$, $F = \\mathbb{R}$ respectively $F = \\mathbb{C}$ be linear so that $f \\neq 0$. Then for any $x_0 \\in X$ for which $f(x_0) \\neq 0$ we have that $\\text{span}(\\ker(f) + \\{x_0\\}) = X$.
proof: Let $x_0 \\in X$ be so that $f(x_0) \\neq 0$. Given any $x \\in X$ we set $\\lambda := \\frac{f(x)}{f(x_0)}$ and note that $f(x - \\lambda x_0) = 0$. Hence $x - \\lambda x_0 \\in \\ker(f)$ and thus $x \\in \\text{span}(\\ker(f) + \\{x_0\\})$. As $x \\in X$ was arbitrary, this establishes the claim.

name: Subspace Separation
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a normed space, $Y$ a proper closed subspace of $X$. Then for any $x_0 \\in X \\setminus Y$ there exists an element $f \\in X^*$ with $\\|f\\| = 1$ so that $f|_Y = 0$ while $f(x_0) = \\text{dist}(x_0, Y)$.
proof:
We define a suitable linear map $g$ on the subspace $U = \text{span}(Y \cup \{x_0\})$ and then use Hahn-Banach to extend $g$ to $f$.

To this end we note that every $u \in U$ can be written uniquely as $u = y + \lambda x_0$ for some $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$ and $y \in Y$ so that defining

$g(y + \lambda x_0) := \lambda d$, where $d := \text{dist}(x_0, Y) > 0$

gives a well defined linear map on $Y$ which has the property that $g(x_0) = d$ and $g|_Y = 0$.

To see that $\|g\|_{U^*} \leq 1$ we note that for any $u = y + \lambda x_0 \in U$

$\|y + \lambda x_0\| = |\lambda| \|x_0 - (-\lambda^{-1}y)\| \geq |\lambda| \inf_{\tilde{y}\in Y} \|x_0 - \tilde{y}\| = |\lambda| d = |g(y + \lambda x_0)|$.

To prove that $\|g\| = 1$ it hence remains to prove that $\|g\| \geq 1$, or equivalently that for any $\varepsilon > 0$ there exists $x \in X \setminus \{0\}$ so that $\frac{|g(x)|}{\|x\|} \geq 1 - \varepsilon$, where it is of course enough to consider $\varepsilon \in (0,1)$. To obtain such an $x$ we note that by the definition of $d = \text{dist}(x_0, Y)$, we can find for any $c > d$, an element $y \in Y$ so that $\|x_0 - y\| < c$. We chose $c = \frac{1}{1-\varepsilon} d$, which is strictly larger than $d$ since $d > 0$, and hence obtain an element $x_0 - y \in X$ for which $\frac{|g(x_0-y)|}{\|x_0-y\|} = \frac{d}{c} = 1 - \varepsilon$ as required. Having thus shown that $\|g\| = 1$ we now obtain the required $f \in X^*$ with $f|_Y = 0$, $f(x_0) = d$ and $\|f\| = \|g\| = 1$ by applying the Theorem of Hahn-Banach.

name: Annihilator Definition
statement:
Given any subset $A \subset X$, we define the annihilator of $A$ to be

$A^\circ := \{f \in X^* : f|_A = 0\}$.

Furthermore, for subsets $T \subset X^*$ we define

$T^\circ := \{x \in X : f(x) = 0 \text{ for all } f \in T\} = \bigcap_{f \in T} \ker(f)$.

name: Annihilator Properties
statement:
Let $(X, \|\cdot\|)$ be a normed space. Then the following hold true:

(i) Let $S \subset X$. Then $\operatorname{span}(S)$ is dense if and only if the annihilator of $S$ is trivial, i.e.

$S^\circ = \{0\} \subset X^*$

(ii) If $T \subset X^*$ is so that $\operatorname{span}(T)$ is dense in $X^*$ then $T^\circ = \{0\} \subset X$.

name: Annihilator Closure
statement: Let $A$ be any subspace of a normed space $X$. Then\n\n$\\overline{A} = (A^\\circ)^\\circ$.
proof: \\begin{proof}\n\
subset$\\: s $(A^\\circ)^\\circ$ is closed, it suffices to prove that $A \\subset (A^\\circ)^\\circ$. Let $a \\in A$. Then by definition of the annihilator of $A$ we know that $f(a) = 0$ for any $f \\in A^\\circ$ and hence that $a \\in (A^\\circ)^\\circ$.\n\n\
supset$\\: uppose that there exists an element $x \\in (A^\\circ)^\\circ$ so that $x \\notin \\overline{A}$. As $\\overline{A}$ is a closed subspace of $X$ we know from Proposition 6.4.2 that there exists some $f \\in X^*$ so that $f(x) \\neq 0$ but with $f|_{\\overline{A}} = 0$, i.e., with $f \\in (\\overline{A})^\\circ$ and hence $f \\in A^\\circ$. But this contradicts the assumption that $x \\in (A^\\circ)^\\circ$.\n\\end{proof}

name: Functional Continuity
statement: Let $X$ be a normed space and let $f : X \\to F$, $F = \\mathbb{R}$ respectively $F = \\mathbb{C}$ be linear. Then the following are equivalent\n\n$\\ker(f)$ is closed $\\Leftrightarrow$ $f \\in X^*$.
proof: \\begin{proof}\n\
Leftarrow$\\: s $f$ is continuous and $\\{0\\}$ is closed we get that the preimage $\\ker(f) = f^{-1}(\\{0\\})$ is also closed.\n\n\
Rightarrow$\\:
he claim is trivial if $f = 0$ so suppose that $f \neq 0$ and let $x_0$ be so that $f(x_0) \neq 0$, where (after replacing $x_0$ by a multiple of $x_0$) we can assume without loss of generality that $f(x_0) = 1$.

We first note that since $\ker(f)$ is closed, we know that $\operatorname{dist}(x_0, \ker(f)) > 0$, compare problem sheet 0. We now claim that for every $x \in X$

$|f(x)| \leq \delta^{-1}\|x\|$ where $\delta := \operatorname{dist}(x_0, \ker(f)) > 0$

which will of course imply that $f \in X^*$.

This claim is trivial for $x \in \ker(f)$ so suppose instead that $f(x) \neq 0$. We note that since $f(x_0) = 1$ and since $f$ is linear we have that $x - f(x)x_0 \in \ker(f)$. Hence also $-\frac{1}{f(x)}(x - f(x)x_0) \in \ker(f)$ and must thus have distance of at least $\delta$ from $x_0$ which implies that

$\delta \leq \left\|x_0 + \frac{1}{f(x)}(x - f(x)x_0)\right\| = \frac{\|x\|}{|f(x)|}$

and thus that indeed $|f(x)| \leq \delta^{-1}\|x\|$.
\end{proof}

name: Riesz representation theorem
statement:
Let $X$ be a real (or complex) Hilbert space and $\ell : X \to \mathbb{R}$ (or $\mathbb{C}$) be a bounded linear functional. Then $\ell$ is of the form

$\ell(y) = \langle y, x \rangle$ for all $y \in X$

for some $x \in X$. Furthermore, the point $x$ is uniquely determined and $\|x\| = \|\ell\|_*$.
proof:
\begin{proof}
If $\ell = 0$, then $x = 0$. Assume henceforth that $\ell \not\equiv 0$. Let $Y$ be the kernel of $\ell$. Then $Y$ is a closed subspace of $X$. By Theorem 1.2.15, $X = Y \oplus Y^\perp$.

Since $Y^{\perp\perp} = Y$ is a strict subspace of $X$ (as $\ell \not\equiv 0$), $Y^\perp$ contains a non-zero element, say $y^\perp$. Note that $\ell(y^\perp) \neq 0$. Then for any $z \in X$, we have

$z - \frac{\ell(z)}{\ell(y^\perp)}y^\perp \in Y = \operatorname{Ker} \ell$

Taking inner product with $y^\perp$ yields

$\langle z, y^\perp \rangle - \frac{\ell(z)}{\ell(y^\perp)}\|y^\perp\|^2 = 0$ for all $z \in X$.

In other words, $x$ can be chosen as

$x = \frac{\ell(y^\perp)}{\|y^\perp\|^2}y^\perp$.

The uniqueness is obvious.

For the last assertion, we note by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality that $\ell(y) = \langle y, x \rangle \leq \|y\|\|x\|$ and so $\|\ell\|_* \leq \|x\|$. On the other hand, we have $\|x\|^2 = \langle x, x \rangle = \ell(x) \leq \|\ell\|_*\|x\|$ and so $\|x\| \leq \|\ell\|_*$. This completes the proof.
\end{proof}

name: Dual space of Lp
statement: Let $\\Omega \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ be measurable, $1 \\leq p < \\infty$ and $1 < q \\leq \\infty$ be so that $\\frac{1}{p} + \\frac{1}{q} = 1$. Then $(L^p(\\Omega))^* \\cong L^q(\\Omega)$ where the associated isometric isomorphism $L : L^q(\\Omega) \\to (L^p(\\Omega))^*$ assigns to each $f \\in L^q(\\Omega)$ the linear map $L(f) \\in (L^p(\\Omega))^*$ defined by $(L(f))(g) = \\int_{\\Omega} f g dx \\in \\mathbb{R}$ for $g \\in L^p(\\Omega)$.
proof:
The proof will be split into two parts. In Part 1, we show that $L$ is well-defined and isometric. In Part 2, we prove that $L$ is surjective.

Part 1: We show that $L$ is well-defined and isometric.

We note that since $p, q$ are so that $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$ we know from Hölder's inequality that the product $fg$ of two functions $f \in L^q(\Omega)$ and $g \in L^p(\Omega)$ is integrable and
$$\left|\int_{\Omega} fg\,dx\right| \leq \|f\|_{L^q} \|g\|_{L^p}.$$

We now remark that since the integral is linear, we have that for all $f, \tilde{f} \in L^q(\Omega)$, $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$ and any $g \in L^p(\Omega)$ that $L(f + \lambda \tilde{f})(g) = Lf(g) + \lambda L\tilde{f}(g)$, i.e., that the map $L: f \mapsto L_f$ is linear. Similarly, given any $f \in L^q(\Omega)$ we have that for any $g, \tilde{g} \in L^p(\Omega)$ and any $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$ that $L_f(g + \lambda\tilde{g}) = L_f(g) + \lambda L_f(\tilde{g})$ so $L_f$ is a linear map from $L^p$ to $\mathbb{R}$ and indeed an element of $(L^p(\Omega))^*$ as it is bounded with
$$\|L_f\|_{(L^p(\Omega))^*} = \sup_{g\in L^q,g\neq 0} \frac{|L_f(g)|}{\|g\|_{L^p}} = \sup_{g\in L^q,g\neq 0} \frac{|\int fg|}{\|g\|_{L^p}} \leq \sup_{g\in L^q,g\neq 0} \frac{\|f\|_{L^q} \|g\|_{L^p}}{\|g\|_{L^p}} = \|f\|_{L^q}$$
where we used Hölder's inequality in the penultimate step.

We finally show that also
$$\|L_f\|_{L^p(\Omega)^*} \geq \|f\|_{L^q}$$
for every $f \in L^q$ and thus that $L$ is indeed isometric.

This proof is a bit technical as we need to be careful with the exponents. We first treat the case that $p > 1$ and hence $q < \infty$.

The estimate is trivial if $f = 0$ so suppose that $f \neq 0$. We choose $g := |f|^{q-2}f$ so that $fg = |f|^q$ and hence $L(f)(g) = \int_{\Omega} |f|^q dx = \|f\|^q_{L^q}$. We now note that since $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$ we have $(q-1)p = q$ and so
$$\|g\|_{L^p} = \left(\int |g|^p dx\right)^{1/p} = \left(\int (|f|^{(q-1)})^p dx\right)^{1/p} = \left(\int |f|^q dx\right)^{1/q \cdot (q-1)} = \|f\|^{q-1}_{L^q}$$
which means that
$$\frac{L_f(g)}{\|g\|_{L^p}} = \frac{\|f\|^q_{L^q}}{\|f\|^{q-1}_{L^q}} = \|f\|_{L^q}$$
and hence that $\|L_f\|_{(L^p)^*} \geq \|f\|_{L^q}$ as claimed.

If $p = 1$ and hence $q = \infty$ then we prove that for any $\varepsilon > 0$ there exists a function $g_\varepsilon \in L^1$ so that $\frac{L_f(g)}{\|g\|_{L^1}} \geq \|f\|_{L^\infty} - \varepsilon$. To this end we consider the set $A_\varepsilon := \{x : |f(x)| \geq \|f\|_{L^\infty} - \varepsilon\}$, which is measurable (and well defined up to a null set). If this set has finite measure then we define $g_\varepsilon(x) := \text{sign}(f(x)) \cdot \chi_{A_\varepsilon}$ which is in $L^1(\Omega)$ with $L^1$-norm equal to the measure of $A_\varepsilon$, which by the definition of the $L^\infty$ norm is positive. As $fg \geq (\|f\|_{L^\infty} - \varepsilon)\chi_{A_\varepsilon}$ we can thus immediately check that $L_f(g) \geq (\|f\|_{L^\infty} - \varepsilon)\|g_\varepsilon\|_{L^1}$ which gives the claimed bound. Finally, if $A_\varepsilon$ has infinite measure, then we can replace $A_\varepsilon$ by any subset $\tilde{A}_\varepsilon \subset A_\varepsilon$ whose measure is finite and positive and apply the above argument for the corresponding function $g_\varepsilon \in L^1$.

Part 2: We show that $L$ is surjective when $\Omega$ is bounded.

Let $\ell \in (L^p(\Omega))^*$ and we would like to find $f \in L^q(\Omega)$ such that $\ell(g) = \int_{\Omega} fg\,dx$ for all $g \in L^p(\Omega)$.

Observe that the set function $\psi(E) = \ell(\chi_E)$ is $\sigma$-additive (that is, a signed measure) and absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure. (Note that $\psi$ is well-defined as $\chi_E \in L^p(\Omega)$, thanks to the boundedness of $\Omega$.) By the Radon-Nikodym theorem (Theorem 7.3.3), there exists a function $f \in L^1(\Omega)$ such that
$$\psi(E) = \int_E f\,dx \text{ for all measurable } E \subset \Omega.$$

This implies that
$$\ell(\chi_E) = \int_E f\,dx \text{ for all measurable } E \subset \Omega,$$
and so by linearity
$$\ell(s) = \int_{\Omega} fs\,dx \text{ for all simple functions } s.$$

Consider $h \in L^p(\Omega) \cap L^\infty(\Omega)$. Recall from Part A integration that there exists a sequence $(h_j)$ of simple functions such that $|h_j| \leq |h|$ and $h_j \to h$ a.e. It then follows by Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem that
$$\ell(h) = \lim_{j\to\infty} \ell(h_j) = \lim_{j\to\infty} \int_{\Omega} fh_j\,dx = \int_{\Omega} \lim_{j\to\infty} fh_j\,dx = \int_{\Omega} fh\,dx.$$

Consider next $g \in L^p(\Omega)$. We approximate $g$ by truncation:
$$g_k(x) = \begin{cases} g(x) & \text{if } |g(x)| \leq k, \\ 0 & \text{otherwise}, \end{cases}$$
so that $g_k \to g$ in $L^p(\Omega)$, in view of Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem. Then
$$\ell(g) = \lim_{k\to\infty} \ell(g_k) = \lim_{k\to\infty} \int_{\Omega} fg_k\,dx,$$
but at this point we have difficulty to interchange the limit and the integration. We circumvent the issue as follows: Consider the function $\tilde{g}_k = |g_k|\text{sign}(f)$. We have
$$\|\ell\|_{(L^p)^*}\|g\|_{L^p} \geq \|\ell\|_{(L^p)^*}\|\tilde{g}_k\|_{L^p} \geq |\ell(\tilde{g}_k)| = \left|\int_{\Omega} f\tilde{g}_k\,dx\right| = \int_{\Omega} |f||g_k|\,dx.$$

Sending $k \to \infty$ and using Lebesgue's monotone convergence theorem, we have $\|\ell\|_{(L^p)^*}\|g\|_{L^p} \geq \int_{\Omega} |f||g|\,dx$, that is $fg$ is integrable. We can now continue the previous chain of identity with Lebesgue's dominated convergence theorem to obtain
