$$\ell(g) = \lim_{k\to\infty} \int_{\Omega} fg_k\,dx = \int_{\Omega} \lim_{k\to\infty} fg_k\,dx = \int_{\Omega} fg\,dx.$$

By the converse of Hölder's inequality, this also implies that $f \in L^q(\Omega)$:
$$\|f\|_{L^q} = \sup_{g\in L^p(\Omega),\|g\|_{L^p}=1} \left|\int_{\Omega} fg\,dx\right| = \sup_{g\in L^p(\Omega),\|g\|_{L^p}=1} |\ell(g)| = \|\ell\|_{(L^p)^*}.$$

This concludes the proof.

name: Radon-Nikodym
statement: Let $\\Omega \\subset \\mathbb{R}^n$ be a bounded (Lebesgue) measurable set and let $\\mu$ be a finite signed measure defined on the $\\sigma$-algebra consisting of measurable subsets of $\\Omega$. Suppose that $\\mu$ is absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure, that is, every set that has zero Lebesgue measure has zero $\\mu$-measure. Then $d\\mu = f dx$ where $f$ is some integrable function with respect to the Lebesgue measure: $\\mu(E) = \\int_E f dx$ for every measurable $E \\subset \\Omega$. Moreover, if $\\mu$ is non-negative, so is $f$.
proof:
We follow the proof of von Neumann. We will only consider the case $\mu$ is non-negative.

Let $X$ be the real Hilbert space $L^2(\Omega, \mu+dx)$ with the norm $\|g\|^2 = \int_{\Omega} |g|^2d\mu+\int_{\Omega} |g|^2 dx$.

Define
$$\ell(g) = \int_{\Omega} g\,dx \text{ for } g \in X.$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, $\ell \in X^*$. Thus, by the Riesz representation theorem, we can find some $h \in X$ such that
$$\ell(g) = \int_{\Omega} gh\,d\mu + \int_{\Omega} gh\,dx \text{ for all } g \in X.$$

This can be rewritten as
$$\int_{\Omega} g(1-h)\,dx = \int_{\Omega} gh\,d\mu \text{ for all } g \in X.$$

We are now tempted to define $f = \frac{1-h}{h}$ and try $g = \frac{1}{h}\chi_E$ in the equation above to conclude. Each of those has complications and we will treat them in order.

(a) Proof of non-negativity and almost everywhere finiteness of $f := \frac{1-h}{h}$. To this end, we need to show that
$$0 < h \leq 1 \text{ except on a set of measure zero.}$$

Let $F = \{h \leq 0\}$. Choosing $g = \chi_F$ in the equation above, we get
$$0 \leq |F| \leq \int_F (1-h)\,dx = \int_F h\,d\mu \leq 0.$$

This implies $|F| = 0$.

Let $G = \{h > 1\}$. We choose $g = \chi_G$ in the equation above and get
$$0 \geq \int_G (1-h)\,dx = \int_G h\,d\mu \geq \mu(G) \geq 0,$$
where the first inequality is strict if $|G| > 0$. This implies that $|G| = 0$. We have thus proved that $0 < h \leq 1$ except on a set of zero Lebesgue measure. Consequently, $f = \frac{1-h}{h}$ is non-negative and almost everywhere finite.

(b) Proof of integrability of $f$ and the identity $\mu(E) = \int_E f\,dx$. For $N > 0$, choosing $g = \min\{\frac{1}{h}, N\}\chi_E$ in the equation above gives
$$\int_E \min\{f, N(1-h)\}\,dx = \int_E \min\{1, Nh\}\,d\mu.$$

As $N \to \infty$, the integrands on the left and the right hand sides increase a.e. in $E$ to $f$ and $1$ respectively. By Lebesgue's monotone convergence theorem, we have
$$\int_E f\,dx = \int_E 1\,d\mu = \mu(E).$$

Note that in the case $E = \Omega$, this gives that $\int_{\Omega} f\,dx = \mu(\Omega) < \infty$ which implies that $f$ is integrable (since $f \geq 0$). The proof is complete.

name: Dual space of ℓp
statement: Let $1 \\leq p < \\infty$ and $1 < q \\leq \\infty$ be so that $\\frac{1}{p} + \\frac{1}{q} = 1$. Then $(\\ell^p)^* \\cong \\ell^q$ where the associated isometric isomorphism $L : \\ell^q(\\mathbb{R}) \\to (\\ell^p(\\mathbb{R}))^*$ assigns to each $x \\in \\ell^q$ the linear map $L(x) \\in (\\ell^p)^*$ given by $(L(x))(y) = \\sum_{j=1}^{\\infty} x_j y_j \\in \\mathbb{R}$ for $y \\in \\ell^p(\\mathbb{R})$.
proof:
The proof that $L$ is a well defined isometric linear map from $\ell^q$ to $(\ell^p)^*$ is exactly the same as for the function spaces $L^p$ (replacing functions by sequences and integral by sums), so we do not repeat it.

Instead we explain how one can prove surjectivity of the map $L$ in case of $p = 1$ to show that indeed $(\ell^1)^* = \ell^\infty$:

Given $f \in (\ell^1)^*$ we define a sequence $x = (x_j)_{j\in\mathbb{N}}$ by setting $x_j = f(e^{(j)})$ where as usual $e^{(j)}$ is the sequence with $e^{(j)}_k = \delta_{jk}$. Then
$$|x_j| \leq \|f\|_{(\ell^1)^*}\|e^{(j)}\|_1 = \|f\|_{(\ell^1)^*}$$
so $x \in \ell^\infty$. We now claim that $L_x = f$. To see this we note that since both $L_x$ and $f$ are linear and as by construction $(L_x)(e^{(j)}) = x_j = f(e^{(j)})$, we know that $f|_Y = L_x|_Y$ for $Y := \text{span}(\{e^{(j)}, j \in \mathbb{N}\})$. As $Y \subset \ell^1$ is dense, compare with the proof of Proposition 5.0.7, we thus obtain from Corollary 4.1.4 that indeed $f = L_x$.

The proof of surjectivity of $L$ for general sequence spaces $\ell^p$, $1 \leq p < \infty$ is very similar (though one needs to be more careful with the exponents).

name: Dual operator
statement: Let $(X, \\|\\cdot\\|_X)$ and $(Y, \\|\\cdot\\|_Y)$ be normed spaces over the same field $F = \\mathbb{R}$ or $F = \\mathbb{C}$ and let $T \\in B(X, Y)$. Then the dual operator $T' : Y^* \\to X^*$ defined by $f \\mapsto T'(f) : x \\mapsto T'(f)(x) := f(Tx)$ is well defined and a bounded linear operator $T' \\in B(Y^*, X^*)$ with $\\|T'\\|_{B(Y^*,X^*)} = \\|T\\|_{B(X,Y)}$.
proof:
As already mentioned, the fact that for each $f \in X^*$ the map $T'(f)$ is linear and that $T$ itself is a linear operator is easily checked (and the proof is exactly the same as in the finite dimensional case that was covered in part A Linear Algebra). We first show that $T'(f) \in X^*$ with
$$\|T'(f)\|_{X^*} \leq \|T\|_{B(X,Y)}\|f\|_{Y^*} \text{ for every } f \in Y^*$$
which ensures that $T'$ is a well defined operator in $B(Y^*, X^*)$ with $\|T'\|_{B(Y^*,X^*)} \leq \|T\|_{B(X,Y)}$. To see this we note that for every $x \in X$ with $\|x\|_X = 1$
$$|T'(f)(x)| = |f(T(x))| \leq \|f\|_{Y^*}\|Tx\|_Y \leq \|f\|_{Y^*}\|T\|_{B(X,Y)}\|x\|_X = \|f\|_{Y^*}\|T\|_{B(X,Y)}$$
so that the inequality follows from the definition of the operator norm. To see that also $\|T'\| \geq \|T\|$ we will prove that
$$\|Tx\|_Y \leq \|T'\|_{B(Y^*,X^*)}\|x\|_X \text{ for all } x \in X$$
which implies that $\|T\| = \inf\{M : \|Tx\| \leq M \|x\|\} \leq \|T'\|$.

This estimate trivially holds true for all $x \in \ker(T)$, so suppose that $Tx \neq 0$. Then Proposition 6.3.1 (which was a consequence of the Theorem of Hahn-Banach) gives us an element $f \in Y^*$ with $\|f\|_{Y^*} = 1$ so that
$$f(Tx) = \|Tx\|.$$

Hence
$$\|Tx\| = f(Tx) = (T'(f))(x) \leq \|T'(f)\|\|x\| \leq \|T'\|\|f\|\|x\| = \|T'\|\|x\|$$
as claimed.

name: Adjoint Operator Properties
statement:
The adjoint operator satisfies the following properties.

(i) $\langle Ax, y\rangle_Y = \langle x, A^*y\rangle_X$.

(ii) There is a unique operator $A^*$ satisfying (i).

(iii) $A^* \in B(Y, X)$.

(iv) If we identify $X$ with $X^*$ and $Y$ with $Y^*$ via the surjective isometric (skew)linear maps $\pi_X$ and $Y$ as in Remark 7.2.2, then $A^* = \pi^{-1}_X A'\pi_Y$.

(v) $\|A\|_{B(X,Y)} = \|A^*\|_{B(Y,X)}$.

(vi) $A^{**} = A$.

(vii) If $A, B \in B(X, Y)$ and $a, b \in C$, then $(aA + bB)^* = \bar{a} A^* + \bar{b} B^*$.

(viii) If $T \in B(X, Y)$ and $S \in B(Y, Z)$, then $(ST)^* = T^*S^*$.

If $X = Y$, we also have that

(viii) $I^*_X = I_X$.

(ix) $A \in B(X)$ is invertible if and only if $A^*$ is invertible.
proof: Exercise.

name: Matrix Adjoint
statement: Let $X = \\mathbb{R}^n$, $Y = \\mathbb{R}^m$ and $Ax = M x$ where $M$ is some $m \\times n$ matrix. Then $A^*$ is given by $A^*y = M^* y$ where $M^*$ is the conjugate transpose of $M$.

name: Integral Operator Adjoint
statement:
Let $X = Y = L^2(0, 1)$ and $A$ be the integral operator

$(Af)(x) = \int_0^1 k(x, y)f(y) dy$

where $k : (0, 1)^2 \to \mathbb{R}$ is a given bounded measurable function. Then $A$ is a linear operator of $L^2(0, 1)$ into itself. The adjoint operator $A^*$, which is also a linear operator of $L^2(0, 1)$ into itself, is given by

$(A^*g)(x) = \int_0^1 k(y, x)g(y) dy$.
proof: This is because, by Fubini's theorem,\n\n$\\langle Af, g\\rangle = \\int_0^1 \\int_0^1 k(x, y) f(y) dy \\bar{g}(x) dx = \\int_0^1 f(y) \\int_0^1 k(x, y) g(x) dx dy = \\langle f, A^*g\\rangle$.

name: Shift Operator Adjoint
statement: Let $X = Y = \\ell^2$ and $R$ be the right-shift $R((x_1, x_2, \\ldots)) = (0, x_1, x_2, \\ldots)$. Then $R^*$ is the left-shift $L((x_1, x_2, \\ldots)) = (x_2, x_3, \\ldots)$.

name: Multiplication Operator Adjoint
statement: Let $X = Y = L^2(\\mathbb{R})$ and $h : \\mathbb{R} \\to \\mathbb{C}$ be a bounded measurable function. Define the multiplication operator $M_h$ by $M_h f(x) = h(x)f(x)$. Then $M_h \\in B(X)$ and $M^*_h = M_{\\bar{h}}$.

name: Kernel-Image Relation
statement:
Let $X$ and $Y$ be Hilbert spaces and $A \in B(X, Y)$. Then

(i) $\operatorname{Ker} A = (\operatorname{Im} A^*)^\perp$.

(ii) $(\operatorname{Ker} A)^\perp = \operatorname{Im} A^*$.
proof: The proof is left as an exercise.

name: Canonical Embedding
statement: Let $(X, \\| \\cdot \\|)$ be a normed space and let $i : X \\to X^{**}$ be the canonical map defined by $(7.7)$. Then $i$ is linear and isometric, i.e.\n\n$\\|i(x)\\|_{X^{**}} = \\|x\\|_X$.
proof:
$i$ is clearly a linear map from $X^* \to \mathbb{R}$ and as for any $f \in X^*$ with $\|f\|_{X^*} = 1$

$|i(x)(f)| = |f(x)| \leq \|f\| \|x\| = \|x\|$

we have that

$\|i(x)\|_{X^{**}} = \sup_{f \in X^*, \|f\|_{X^*} = 1} |f(x)| \leq \|x\|$.

To see that also $\|i(x)\| \geq \|x\|$ we now choose $f \in X^*$ with $\|f\|_{X^*} = 1$ as in Proposition 6.3.1 so that $f(x) = \|x\|$.

We note that this argument is essentially just a repetition of the proof of Corollary 6.3.2 (i) which directly gives that $\|i(x)\| = \|x\|$.

name: Completion Existence
statement:
Let $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ be any normed space. Then $(X, \| \cdot \|)$ is isometrically isomorphic to $i(X)$ which can be seen as dense subspace of the Banach space $(Y, \| \cdot \|_{X^{**}})$ where $Y = \overline{i(X)} \subset X^{**}$.

A Banach space $(Y, \| \cdot \|_Y)$ into which $X$ embeds isometrically as a dense subset is called completion of $X$. Such a completion is determined up to isometric isomorphisms, i.e. given any two spaces $Y$, $\tilde{Y}$ so that there exist isometric maps $J : X \to Y$ respectively $\tilde{J} : X \to \tilde{Y}$ for which $J(X)$ (respectively $\tilde{J}(X)$) is dense in $Y$ (respectively $\tilde{Y}$), we have that there is a (unique) isometric isomorphism $I : Y \to \tilde{Y}$ so that

$\tilde{J} = I \circ J$.
proof: Indeed, this map $I$ is determined as the unique extension of $\\tilde{J} \\circ H$, $H : J(X) \\to X$ the inverse of the bijective map $J : X \\to J(X)$, from the dense subspace $J(X) \\subset Y$ to the whole space $Y$, compare Theorem 4.1.3.
